generation: Another week has flown by. Yesterday, I drove past the new house and saw that the front window was covered with boxes. We're eagerly anticipating receiving the keys at closing—I'm getting really excited! If everything goes smoothly this week, we'll be ready to close a week from Wednesday. Last night, I stayed up past 3:00 AM watching movies with Bethany. There's been a lot of movie watching happening here lately. Here's my recap: we watched "Thirteen" last night—a film every parent of a teenager should see. It surpassed my expectations. Then we watched "Gigli," which lived up to its poor reviews, but we had to see it for ourselves.

Summer television used to be a wasteland filled with reruns, but now two exciting new shows have captured my attention. I've been watching both shows religiously over the past week. One of them, "Blow Out," features an unexpectedly flamboyant concept with hardly any visible LGBTQIA+ representation. It follows hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who is aiming to open a second branch of his widely successful West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Ordinarily, I wouldn't be interested at all. However, while flipping through channels, I happened upon Jonathan, who, with a mix of vanity and monotony, gazed at an empty space on Rodeo Drive and declared, "I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!" Strangely, I was hooked. Not since "Rocco" have I found a character this compelling on television, despite their apparent foolishness.

What a week it's been... I'm dealing with tendonitis in my right shoulder, specifically under my shoulder blade. Whenever I overuse it, particularly with computer work, the pain is intense. At this point, I can hardly move my arm because I spent a lot of time updating my website and tackling other online tasks. Drawing takes much more effort now, and the lack of sleep only worsens the situation. While I'm not in the best spirits at the moment, I'm confident I'll recover soon. On a brighter note, my mom's surgery went well. Her eyesight is gradually returning; she can now discern fuzzy shapes and identify colors, although she remains significantly visually impaired. We're hopeful that she'll fully regain her vision soon.

The Kindness of Strangers... Today I attempted to do laundry with the kids and quickly discovered how even the simplest tasks can turn into daunting ordeals. Amidst the chaos, I also found out just how wonderfully kind strangers can be, expecting nothing in return other than the joy of being kind. Believe me, it wasn't like they were trying to impress me—I was disheveled, covered in kid drool, and wearing my trusty 'laundry day' attire. Plus, let’s just say my personal hygiene wasn't at its peak, so there was no scent-based motivation either! At this moment, I'm multitasking: writing this post while watching a collection of No Doubt music videos, all from the comfort of my desk in my room.

It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I find myself in my bedroom working on the computer of the personnel director from my job. I don't mind helping out, but I sometimes wonder why I so often end up fixing other people's computers as a favor. Could you remind me what I wrote about previously? Or perhaps it's time for another installment in the "Is This a Date?" saga. I encourage everyone to be thoughtful before taking action. If someone isn't ready to do so, perhaps they should consider staying in bed and opting for a restful sleep instead. I'm genuinely frustrated with careless behavior. Have you ever experienced a moment when you start reflecting on life? Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had, as early as 1996, forewarned of the looming threat of the emergence of a so-called "third Islamic state" in the region. T. V. Rajeswar, who previously led the Intelligence Bureau and now serves as the Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had anticipated this serious danger in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times back in 1996. Alternatively, should we dismiss Rajeswar as a covert communalist unfit to continue as the Governor of Uttar Pradesh simply because he penned such forecasts?

Last night in class, we explored this week's assigned reading: Edward S. Casey's "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World." The first chapter, "Implacement," and the second, "Displacement," delved into how our modern world emphasizes time as the key framework: we are constantly racing against time, trying to save it, or catching up just in time. Casey argues that centering culture around place fosters a more rooted community. (This is a brief summary, offered humbly in case my professor or any classmates read this post.) So far, this book is the first in our course that has truly captivated my interest.

In the fall of 1974, it felt like the thirteenth attempt to conquer the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I wasn't then, nor am I now, someone who naturally gravitates towards mathematics. In fact, I have a strong aversion to it. You get the picture: I am truly math-phobic. As I endeavored to unravel the mysteries of algebra, the doorbell unexpectedly rang. Reluctantly, I set down my book to answer the door, only to find no one there. Frustrated, I returned to my studies, and just as I began to grasp a fleeting moment of clarity, the doorbell disrupted my thoughts once more. Instantly, my fragile breakthrough vanished. Once again, I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. It was exactly what a struggling math student didn't need—an unwelcome prank.

Republican Party Faces Criticism Over Voter Registration at Naturalization Ceremonies

Naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville will be relocated due to concerns following allegations that Republican activists were registering new citizens as members of their party. Reported by Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy, the citizenship ceremony initially proceeded as expected, with nearly 200 attendees taking part and becoming new Americans. Just before leaving the event on June 29, an immigration official encouraged these new citizens to visit a voter registration table—an ordinary feature at such ceremonies. However, this table was different: Republican volunteers were distributing the forms, and the party affiliation box had already been pre-checked to register each new voter as a Republican. This appeared suspicious to Linda Cross, who was present to witness her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

I found the concept of treating flag-burning as an offense intriguing, as it might have offered historical figures accused of witchcraft an alternative fate. As a non-American blogger, I've been hesitant to weigh in on certain debates, especially those concerning flags. However, given that I initiated the topic (though not the act of flag-burning), I should probably express my views. To begin with, I find the idea of enacting a law against flag-burning entirely irrational. When we start granting any symbol—regardless of its nature—an unquestioning reverence and legal protection, we take a significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently ambiguous; they don’t intrinsically stand for anything. What matters is the meaning we assign to them or how they are perceived.

Introducing PulpFiction 1.0 from Freshly Squeezed Software, the latest entrant in the realm of Atom/RDF/RSS readers! This application offers a wealth of features typical of native apps. However, as a heads-up, it's not freely available, which is a recurring topic of interest online. You can explore PulpFiction with a 15-day trial before deciding to either revert to other options or invest $25 to continue usage. It seems that Wizards of the Coast has lost touch with this spirit. In the digital platform, playing with friends yields no gold, which is vital for progression in the game. Gold is so crucial that there's a daily earning limit, which makes sense, given that gold is the key to unlocking everything within the game. However, brace yourself for the tedious grind of 1v1 battles against either the computer or random opponents—with whom you can't communicate. Choosing the free-to-play path means enduring roughly four hours of solo play each day for over a month to gather the necessary cards.

As the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the drawbacks first. I'm generally not a fan of prequels because they move backward in a narrative rather than advancing it (a common issue with all prequels). Nevertheless, they often add depth to the storyline. Unfortunately, the combat in this game feels less refined than the sharp mechanics achieved in Arkham City. At the time of writing this review (October 26, 2013), there's a game-breaking bug that prevents the completion of a side mission, although the main storyline remains unaffected. Additionally, some gadgets are assigned to impractical hotkeys, requiring you to stretch across the keyboard. This might not seem significant, but it can disrupt your combo in the heat of combat.

There were numerous issues that I encountered, making it difficult to even begin this review. All my concerns are related to MyCareer. My player is an outside scorer, a point guard standing at 1.71m, with maxed-out stats and all the necessary perks. Yet, can anyone explain why shooting ability seems to be influenced by height? How is it that a person who is 1.74m cannot excel at shooting like someone who is 1.71m? In real life, I am 1.87m tall, and when I created my first player at this height, I noticed that I couldn't achieve a shooting skill higher than 89. Why is this? It feels discriminatory! Moreover, why doesn't the game inform me of these limitations before I create a character, or even alert me when I hit the skill ceiling after weeks of playing?

In my opinion, this installment of Assassin's Creed has perfected its mechanics across the board, from ship battles and sailing to hunting and parkour. I found myself much more invested in this particular character. Although the story begins on a shaky note, it significantly improves as you progress, which I feel is a common trait in every Assassin's Creed game. Edward, along with the side characters, was truly captivating. The collectibles in this game felt meaningful, unlike in any previous iterations, perhaps because they seemed to serve a greater purpose within the game. While not essential, they were enjoyable to collect, and the rewards were well-balanced.

While I wouldn't personally recommend this game, it wasn't entirely awful either. The gunplay holds up well, as long as you have the funds to buy gun parts. This highlights my primary issue with the game: it's heavily reliant on a pay-to-win model. If I could overlook that aspect, the game would actually be quite enjoyable. The hardsuit is a blast to use, and the HRV feature is a fantastic concept. I would choose this game over any Call of Duty title anytime, but its pay-to-win microtransaction approach is discouraging for me. If you're comfortable with this model, feel free to enjoy it. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, it's best to pass on this one; it simply isn't suited to our preferences.

Although not without its flaws, this game has provided a highly enjoyable experience. The save system and the potential for sudden character death can be frustrating. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around the 10-hour mark of a 20-hour game. I would have appreciated having a save point to restart from at that moment. To address this, I've started using a third-party mod or save tool to prevent such setbacks. Additionally, the aiming reticle feels a bit too small, and the zoom feature could be more powerful. Despite these issues, the game has been a thrilling ride. While I don't usually gravitate towards zombie-themed games, the blend of strategy, missions, and the first-person shooter/beat 'em up elements is fantastic. I find myself playing whenever I can, always tempted to complete just one more mission or make one more supply run—or sometimes escaping to a safe spot before I log out.

This strategy game is truly exceptional! Having played every other war game, including European Escalation and ALB, I can confidently say this one fits in seamlessly. The sheer number of units available is impressive, and while I can't pinpoint the exact count, there are a vast amount to choose from! The graphics are stunning, the audio is immersive, and overall, the gameplay is nothing short of epic. Even the in-game chat box at the main menu is surprisingly entertaining. However, for those who expect an 'easy' experience or are new to the strategy genre, be prepared for a learning curve. Don't be discouraged by losses; you will lose many units. Just ensure you plan strategically, and always include anti-air and anti-tank defenses.

Initially, I had a negative bias towards this game and was hesitant to purchase it. The concept of a portal gun and portals struck me as peculiar, even though I'm a fan of science fiction. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The humor and voice acting in this game are outstanding—absolutely remarkable. Although there's an occasional hint of cheesiness, each character possesses a distinct sense of humor and personality, adding depth to the story. The level design is simply spectacular. I must mention that I never played the first Portal game, but after experiencing the sequel, I am now considering making time to play it someday. Had it not been for the sequel, I might never have given it a try.

For those in their thirties, especially in the UK, this is a delightful trip down memory lane. It hearkens back to the days of enduring the often-aggravating Timmy Mallett just to catch the five-minute Transformers cartoon segment. Familiar voices like Optimus Prime, Megatron, and Bumblebee make their return, instantly sparking recognition. The iconic transformation sound from the cartoons is faithfully recreated. Visually, the cel-shaded graphics are spot on, perfectly capturing the essence of Generation One. Beyond nostalgia, this is an incredibly enjoyable game with expertly crafted combat mechanics. Transforming during battles is frequently necessary and seamlessly integrated into combos, offering a unique experience compared to High Moon's outstanding War for Cybertron and Fall of Cybertron games. Additionally, there is a significant emphasis on melee combat, although certain foes, such as the Seekers, necessitate switching to ranged blasters for effective engagement.

This game offers stunning 4k resolution at 60fps with a GTX 970, includes dual audio options, and comes with Neptune gear—what's not to like? Check out the video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo. It’s an excellent port and a perfect starting point for newcomers to the series. Be aware, though, that there is a significant amount of dialogue, which you can skip if you prefer. While I recommend using a gamepad for the best experience, I personally encountered no issues with a keyboard and mouse setup, both of which are fully customizable. The pricing feels reasonable, and I would have been satisfied even if I had purchased it outright. More than half of the DLC is included for free, offering plenty to enjoy. I highly recommend this game to fans of JRPGs, anime, and visual novels, so long as you’re okay with longer intermissions between the action. Cheers! You can also explore a no-commentary playlist here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_.

From the very beginning, I encountered no performance issues with this game, even at its initial release. With all the subsequent patches, it plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, it's an incredibly fun and engaging game, despite some aspects that might be a bit irksome—such as the city area that repopulates with new enemies every time you advance the story. I found particular enjoyment in the 'dual play' segments, where you can control Batman alongside another character. The option to switch between a controller for most game segments and a mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments was a much-appreciated feature. Navigating the Batmobile through the free-roam city, especially during pursuits of the APC commanders, becomes quite delightful. Once you've mastered using the brakes to skid around corners, driving around the city becomes a truly gratifying experience.

English isn't my first language; I'm Dutch. Please excuse any typos or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I'll break down this review into several categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, and replayability.

**Graphics:** The game is designed in a comic-like style, which works perfectly. The graphics are clean and well-defined, with no unnecessary details, and the color schemes are pleasing. You can set the graphics to 'high' without putting a strain on your system. I play the game on an i5 Pentium processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card and 8GB of memory, and it runs flawlessly on Windows 8.1.

**Controls:** The game can be played using a keyboard and mouse or an Xbox controller, offering flexibility in how you choose to interact with it.

After spending two hours immersed in this game, I find myself thoroughly entertained. It's incredibly funny, with robust gameplay, stunning art design, and unexpectedly high-quality and fitting music. The story and world are captivating, and the puzzles offer enjoyable challenges. However, what truly sets this game apart is its comedic brilliance. If you've experienced any RPGs since the genre's inception, you'll appreciate the clever jokes, parodies, and references that fill the game. Even newcomers to RPGs will likely find the humor delightful. For fans of classics like Final Fantasy 7 or X, this is a must-play. Without revealing too much, I had to take a break after two hours because I couldn't stop laughing and smiling. What a joy this game has been so far.

I genuinely apologize, as I always try to support free-to-play games and indie developers. However, I did not enjoy this game. Its description seemed perfect for me, but the execution was lacking. Although I am a fan of puzzle and exploration games, I found this one to be entirely unintuitive. Even after searching for ways to progress, the gameplay itself failed to engage me. Additionally, the absence of a pause button—or my inability to find one—is a significant flaw, considering many sequences are timed. Furthermore, the game feels more like a series of cut scenes than actual gameplay, leaving me frequently tapping my fingers in boredom.

This game left me breathless; I hardly know where to begin. The experience was stunning, captivating me from the story to the graphics. It wasn't just a narrative; it truly immersed me, making me feel part of the character's journey, unraveling what awaited in the tale they were weaving. The gameplay was exceptional, and I discovered so much about myself—especially my unexpected fear of heights, which became apparent in the chilling ice caverns. My heart raced constantly, but my determination to support Uncle Fred pushed me onward. Should you ever release a DLC or a sequel, I'd be the first to purchase it and wholeheartedly recommend it to everyone I know. My deepest thanks to everyone involved in creating this masterpiece; you've crafted an utterly beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where your objective is to develop your civilization to achieve specific goals or 'victories'. Unlike the previous installments, which unfolded against Earth's historical timeline—covering eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and the Modern Age—this game is set in a futuristic scenario where your mission is to colonize a new planet. What I particularly appreciate about this game is that 2K Games took a fresh approach by implementing innovative mechanics such as the affinity system and the orbital layer. However, I found that these new mechanics could sometimes make the game feel a bit overwhelming. An area where I believe the game could be enhanced is by incorporating new artwork, particularly in the environments you encounter during interactions with other leaders.

Fantastic game! It offers an incredible amount of replayability and is an immensely enjoyable zombie survival experience. It definitely ranks among my top five zombie games I've ever played. After spending over 60 hours with it, I can confidently say that it's one of the most "realistic" zombie games out there. The game is crafted in the style of survival horror, requiring you to conserve ammo, treat your injuries, and take medication when infected, among other aspects. Additionally, the zombies are impressively animated, especially considering it's a free-to-play game. Note: I highly recommend playing with one or two friends for the best experience, though the community is very welcoming, and you can often make new friends or chat with others in the game via text or voice communication.

February 7, 2014 - It's unfortunate that I can't wholeheartedly recommend or enjoy this game. From the brief time I've played, I can tell I'd be hooked if it weren't for two major issues. First, the absence of Australian servers is a significant problem. Playing with a single red connection bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and results in unbearable lag. Incredibly, I even experienced stuttering and lag during the offline training mode (how does that even happen?). Combine this with poor ping, and it completely ruins the gameplay experience. Secondly, there's a severe issue with graphical artifacts affecting everything, from menus and backgrounds to training and in-game visuals. I've never encountered this problem with my current graphics card setup. I initially thought it might be due to my overclocked settings, but reverting my GPU to its default state made no difference.

Late last night, I completed this. While the plot itself isn't particularly deep or captivating, the storytelling truly sets it apart. The atmosphere is richly immersive, and the numerous collectibles significantly enhance the experience. I gained quite a bit of insight into the Batman universe, but I was a bit disappointed by the limited number of bosses in the game. However, this seems like a great opportunity for future installments to address. The combat strikes a good balance in terms of challenge, leaning slightly towards the easier side. Upgrading Batman himself isn't the most satisfying aspect, but enhancing and acquiring gadgets throughout the campaign introduces refreshing new gameplay mechanics. Plus, accessing previously unreachable areas contributes to a rewarding sense of progression.

To the Moon" transcends being just a game; it is an unforgettable experience, ranking among the most impactful of my life. If you found Telltale's "The Walking Dead" to be poignant, prepare yourself—"To the Moon" surpasses it in every way. Never have I felt so crestfallen yet simultaneously fulfilled by a fictional narrative. In my view, this work stands as a pinnacle of storytelling, complemented by an exquisitely charming and fitting soundtrack. Although the controls can be a bit cumbersome and the gameplay isn't its strongest suit, the story is so captivating that these issues seemed insignificant to me. The game also excels in humor, which is seamlessly woven into the narrative without detracting from its profound nature. And, for fans, there are endless references to Doctor Who to be enjoyed.

Bastion is an exceptionally captivating game with a compelling storyline. Set in the aftermath of a mysterious calamity, your journey begins with rebuilding the bastion. The game offers a plethora of choices that influence your progress, including decisions on construction for strategic advantages, selection of weapons and their enhancements, as well as choosing tonics that grant bonus effects. The art style and soundtrack are remarkable, infusing the post-apocalyptic world with vibrant colors, proving that the end times need not be drab. A standout feature is the dynamic narration, which reacts to your actions as a player. For instance, if you choose to replace one weapon with another at the armory, the narration adapts to reflect your decision, further immersing you in the game.

I initially purchased this game during its early development phase, back when "spacebux" was the sole currency and there wasn't a "tech tree." At that time, the game truly shone. The weapons were all equally overpowered, which eliminated any issues of imbalance—any player could defeat any other at any moment. Additionally, the game used to offer unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. Considering the game's premise of featuring "bajillions of guns," you would expect it to provide more than just six weapon slots and three loadouts before requiring additional payment to unlock more. I once had an arsenal spanning three pages and was brimming with new ideas for expansion, as that was where I personally found the excitement and enjoyment.

This game turned out to be an unexpected treasure. Although rave reviews can sometimes exaggerate a product's appeal, in this instance, they truly capture the enjoyment this delightful little game offers. It uniquely combines elements of a classic 2D platformer with those of a MOBA, pulling it off with flair. To my surprise, I enjoyed playing characters that I'd typically overlook in other MOBA games. Initially, I thought this might not extend to all character types, but I decided to try a melee tank nonetheless. I was pleasantly surprised by the experience, which motivated me to explore more characters as I unlocked them through gameplay. The art style and interface possess a peculiar charm that captivated me. I even adopted one of the characters as my avatar and chose a game-related wallpaper after creating a card set.

I've just started playing this game, and I absolutely love it. With my headphones on, I completely immerse myself for hours at a time. It's been a long time since a game has captivated me like this. The music perfectly sets the atmosphere, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls function flawlessly. I eagerly anticipate each combat encounter, and the developers have done an excellent job optimizing it. I had my reservations about the naval combat system, but now I thoroughly enjoy decimating multiple fleets simultaneously. The only way to lose in this game is by failing to retreat. If the combat becomes too intense, just pull back, regroup, and launch a counter-offensive. Thank you, developers, for creating such an amazing experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced significant changes, particularly affecting the series' protagonist, Dante. Although long-time fans might feel uneasy about the transformation of their cherished character, these changes are undoubtedly beneficial, as demonstrated by Ninja Theory's new game. DmC provides an excellent entry point for newcomers to the series. It explores the beginnings of a once cynical and arrogant Dante, detailing his evolution from self-interest to selflessness. The game skillfully crafts a clear narrative arc for this reimagined Dante, making him an intriguing character to follow. The story follows Dante as he is drawn into the corrupt world he had previously chosen to ignore.

Where do I begin with this truly magnificent game? Its story is irresistibly charming, filled with rich details and bursting with joy, clever humor, playful dogs, and hidden surprises. It expertly balances seriousness with humor, offering funny moments when least expected. The character design is exceptional, featuring a diverse array of personalities, each with their own secrets. What truly sets this RPG apart is the unique concept of not having to kill anyone—an unprecedented approach in the genre. Drawing significant inspiration from EarthBound, one of the finest RPGs out there, this game quickly distinguishes itself as a standout experience. Moreover, it boasts an unforgettable soundtrack, among the best I've heard in years.

I'm recommending this only because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. In my experience, however, the game fell flat. Half of its narrative relies heavily on shock value, which neither surprised nor emotionally affected me. This could be due to my own desensitization, or perhaps the content was too simplistic to evoke a response. The other half of the game attempts to portray the mental decline of a character, dealing with themes like obsession, hallucination, and depression, which is intriguing in concept. Yet, the entire experience lasted just 10 minutes, even with my thorough engagement in reading and absorbing every detail.

Let me tell you why "Portal" is such a remarkable game. As a puzzle game, it introduces an intriguing concept and then lets you explore it on your own. It's a brilliant way to challenge your intellect while still ensuring you have a great time. Even though it doesn't focus heavily on narrative, "Portal" laid the groundwork for one of the most celebrated games of 2011. I still find myself revisiting it whenever I'm bored, enjoying the experience of reliving a true classic. 

In terms of gameplay, "Portal" is elegantly straightforward. You use portals to navigate and solve puzzles, incorporating buttons that activate various elements in the puzzles. These buttons come in two types: one that you simply press and another that requires a cube to engage.

If you can overlook the bugs—which, for me, were just two: one minor and one more annoying (both of which have now been fixed, significantly increasing my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120)—I wholeheartedly recommend this as a space exploration game. I noticed that many reviews focus on system specifications, so here are mine: Intel i5 6600k processor (approximately €200), Radeon RX480 graphics card (approximately €200), Z170 Pro-Gaming motherboard (approximately €150), and 16GB of DDR4 RAM (approximately €70), totaling around €650. This set-up is definitely in the mid-range price category, and it’s relatively new. I’m experiencing almost constant 60+ FPS with high settings and V-Sync enabled. I honestly find it hard to believe that 90% of the comments claim to have an overkill setup but still achieve only 20 FPS.

Do you remember "Age of Mythology?" It's been quite a while since we've seen an RTS game of similar caliber. However, Divinity: Dragon Commander comes remarkably close to being one of my personal favorites in the RTS genre. It combines this with an expansive, Risk-like grand strategy mode that perfectly complements the experience. I strive to remain objective, but it's hard not to be impressed by a game that lets you transform into a dragon, assisting your troops through support, attacks, and even directing unit production, movement, and spawning simultaneously. While I appreciate the complexity of modern RTS games like Civilization V, these titles often try to pack numerous intricate mechanics, graphs, and resources into a single, convoluted gameplay mode.

Undertale transcends its individual elements to create an extraordinary experience. While its graphics effectively capture a retro charm and its music is delightful on its own, together they create truly breathtaking and powerful moments. The script is a masterful blend of comedy, drama, heartbreak, and hope, often intertwining all these elements simultaneously, all while cleverly subverting traditional RPG tropes. This doesn't even touch upon its world-building, characters, storyline, and gameplay, all of which deserve extensive praise. In short, if you enjoy RPGs, you should play this game. If you're a fan of video games, you must play this game. If you can spare seven hours in your life, make the time to play this game.

I've only had this game for a few months, but in that brief time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an outstanding one. The developers are highly engaged with the community, which is evident in the numerous discussion forums and dev diaries. The game's mechanics have a rather steep learning curve, which I'm still working to understand; however, this complexity provides a wide array of strategic options to achieve goals and capitalize on situations. In my opinion, the game offers almost endless replayability. I find myself thoroughly engaged in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough is progressing.

Warframe initially provides an entertaining experience that lasts for the first few hours of gameplay. However, after this initial excitement, players may notice a repetitive pattern in its combat, enemies, and overall gameplay. One significant advantage of Warframe is the dedication of its developers, who frequently release updates that introduce substantial content, including sweeping system changes, new Warframes, and additional features and tweaks. While Warframe is enjoyable for casual play, it may not maintain your interest for more than a few months unless you genuinely enjoy grinding. The silver lining is that the game is free, making it worthwhile to give it a try. If you're seeking a quick gaming experience, it's definitely worth exploring.

This game is incredibly dull. I purchased it thinking it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', the beloved PS2 classic, but unfortunately, it falls far short of that expectation. The concept involves rolling up increasingly larger objects to grow bigger, but the gameplay lacks fluidity, the levels aren't creative, and the overall experience is like a bizarre horror show. It's not the entertaining kind of horror; rather, it leaves you feeling unsettled and questioning the very essence of life. Every creature in the game, from small animals to humans, feels lifeless, leading me to wonder if the developers had an interest in taxidermy.

As someone deeply interested in politics, I was initially quite excited to hear about a game simulating the journey to becoming president. I thought, "Wow, a game exploring the road to the presidency? That sounds intriguing!" Unfortunately, it didn’t quite meet my expectations. The game begins by asking you to choose between the Republican and Democratic parties, with no option for an independent or third-party candidate. Despite my slight disappointment, I remained hopeful and decided to proceed to explore what the game had to offer. I must admit that while the character customization is somewhat limited, it's quite entertaining to experiment with. It’s the only time in a campaign setting where you can humorously decide whether to wear your head or not.

At the time of writing this review, I've logged 8.6 hours to reach the game's conclusion, found 10 out of 25 collectibles, and earned none of the 15 achievements. 

What I liked:
- The visuals were impressive, particularly up until the final level set in the ice caves.
- While the story isn't particularly strong, the ending scene after the credits somewhat justified my investment of time in the game.

What I disliked:
- The visuals in the last level are rather dull.
- The gameplay in the final level becomes excessively challenging, leading to frustration as it requires repeated attempts to succeed.
- The achievements are overly difficult—only 13 out of 15 have been achieved by less than 2.1% of players.

Pros: The graphics are impressive.

Cons: The game has several issues. Bugs are prevalent, particularly in the environment, which can cause your character to get stuck or result in your shots hitting invisible barriers despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy. The gameplay feels overly guided, offering too much handholding. The artificial intelligence appears poorly designed, and enemies always seem to know your location once you're spotted. Their accuracy is unrealistically perfect, reminiscent of the frustrating precision seen in the first Ghost Warrior game. The checkpoint and save system is poorly implemented, and the story is dull and uninspiring. I wouldn’t recommend this game unless it’s heavily discounted—at least 90% off. Even then, playing it feels like a tedious chore, endured only to move on to another game in my collection. Given the time I found myself stuck in the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally monotonous, providing relief only upon its completion), I doubt I'll play this one through to the end.

Review from November 29, 2015:

Do not purchase this game. The servers are offline, so you cannot play. No compres este juego, los servidores están fuera de línea, no puedes jugar. However, during the brief period I was able to play, I found it enjoyable. As the Steve Miller Band song goes, "Go on, take the money and run..." [Link to song: https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54]

English Review:
After just 73 minutes of gameplay, I was hooked! This game is incredible. Some weapons are overpowered, and the matchmaking can be uneven at times, but compared to Battlefield 3, it's not as bad. In Battlefield 3, the matchmaking would unfairly pit new players against high-level ones, who didn't seem human as shooting them in the face had no effect!

I can certainly understand why others enjoy this game, but it simply didn't resonate with me. Owning a Vive, I prefer games that utilize a room-scale setup with controllers. Although the game's vast universe is initially awe-inspiring, I found its size to be more of a hurdle than an asset. The steep learning curve and the considerable time investment required to experience anything captivating at the start were off-putting for me. Perhaps if I had more patience and gaming time, I might find it engaging. However, since I lack both, I’d prefer to explore other VR games instead.

This is unquestionably my all-time favorite first-person shooter game. It's not designed for those who enjoy reckless, run-and-gun tactics. The recoil and ballistics are incredibly realistic. A single bullet to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle-caliber weapon usually results in death, unless it's just a graze. Bullets drop over long distances, and maintaining accuracy requires short, controlled bursts. There's no infinite supply of ammunition—you'll end up with partially filled magazines if you consistently reload halfway through. Sprinting endlessly isn't possible either; after running for a while, your aim will falter as you catch your breath. To improve steadiness, rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or use a window sill for support when aiming. Standing accuracy is less reliable.

I must start by mentioning that I didn't buy the game "EU" when it was initially released. Instead, I got it during a sale that also included "EW," so I didn't encounter the same issues some players reported with the game. I really enjoyed it; the game was challenging in the beginning but very rewarding once you mastered it. As for "XCOM 2," I absolutely love it. The game runs smoothly for me on medium settings, and I'm using a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game defaulted to high settings, and it ran a bit sluggishly—not enough to be unplayable, but noticeable. When I switched to medium settings, everything ran smoothly. I might just be fortunate with my gaming experiences, but it seems to me that a lot of the negative reviews are coming from people with unrealistic expectations.

The game offers a compelling RPG leveling system, a wide array of ship types, and physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles. It features easy-to-master resource management and a dark sense of humor. However, it can become grind-heavy if you don't make the most of the civilian station types, and the AI teammates are somewhat lacking. There's a limited variety of equipment and leveling skills, with no branching paths. Nevertheless, this game is immensely enjoyable. Despite its drawbacks, there is ample room for strategy and variety. It starts off at a fast pace and continues to be engaging. Although the equipment range is limited, there's always a new ship to unlock or skill to enhance. To extend the game's lifespan, mods are a key component. "Fight for Universe" is a standout, but "Big Fight for Beef" is also a great addition.

World leaders converge to confront global uncertainties as over 2,000 business and political figures descend on Davos, Switzerland, for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). During this five-day event, topics such as China's economic influence and Iraq's future post-election will take center stage. Notable attendees include UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, joining over 20 other government leaders and heads of state. In contrast to prior years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued, as anti-globalization activists have canceled a weekend demonstration. Meanwhile, the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the World Social Forum, a counter-event scheduled to coincide with the more opulent gathering in Davos.

As the deadline approaches for the Fiat-GM agreement, both automotive giants have until midnight on February 1st to resolve their conflict over a possible acquisition. This deadline is crucial as it would allow Fiat to sell its car division to General Motors, a provision stemming from their 2000 alliance. However, GM, grappling with its own financial losses in its European division, is now reluctant to take on the financially troubled Fiat unit. News of stalled negotiations led to a 1.2% drop in Fiat's share price on Tuesday, following a 4% increase on Monday prompted by speculation of a lucrative settlement. GM reportedly proposes to pay approximately $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to disengage from the agreement, asserting that the deal was nullified by Fiat's decision to divest its finance arm and dilute GM's stake through a capital restructuring. The original 2000 agreement emerged during a competitive period when GM and DaimlerChrysler vied for a partnership with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has voiced strong criticism regarding the vast sums of money spent on the Iraq war and conflicts in the Middle East, arguing that these funds would have been better used to alleviate poverty. As the leader of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, he shared his thoughts on BBC Radio 4 and planned to emphasize his perspective during his Christmas Midnight Mass. In his Christmas address, he condemned the Iraq war as a "terrible" misuse of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have publicly opposed the war. On the BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day segment, the cardinal highlighted the misallocation of "billions" towards warfare instead of efforts to lift people out of severe poverty, malnourishment, and disease. He urged for 2005 to become a pivotal year for campaigning to "make poverty history.

British Stars Missed Out on Major Oscars

Hopes for British success at the Oscars were disappointed as UK stars went home empty-handed in the acting and directing categories. Despite receiving three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" did not clinch the awards for either Best Director or Best Screenplay, and lead actress Imelda Staunton also went unrecognized. Kate Winslet was bested by Hilary Swank for Best Actress, and both Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo fell short in their bids for Best Supporting Actor. However, Andrea Arnold from the UK emerged victorious, winning the Short Film Award for her gripping drama, "Wasp." Reflecting on her win, Arnold, who was a presenter on children's television shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, described the experience as "totally overwhelming." "Wasp," which tells the story of a single mother struggling to get by, triumphed over entries by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, the screenwriter and producer best known for her role in creating the 1970s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54 after battling cancer. Hill co-wrote the 1978 film, which featured Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter haunted by a psychopath. Under the direction of John Carpenter, the film grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) globally, setting a record for independent films at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, she started her career as a production assistant, advancing through the industry to become an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. Hill is celebrated as a trailblazer for women in film, taking on roles during the 1970s that were typically filled by men.

According to recent research, high-speed broadband is significantly empowering individuals to express themselves online. A study by the UK think-tank Demos reveals that one in four broadband users in Britain regularly uploads content and maintains personal websites. The report highlights that the availability of constant, fast internet connections is transforming how people engage with the web. Currently, over five million households in the UK are equipped with broadband, and this figure continues to rise rapidly. The Demos report investigates the influence of broadband on users' online behaviors, discovering that more than half of broadband users access the internet before having breakfast. Moreover, one in five users confessed to waking up in the middle of the night specifically to browse the web. The report further emphasizes that broadband is motivating individuals to take a more engaged and participative approach to the online world.

Yukos Returns to U.S. Courts: The Russian oil and gas company, Yukos, is scheduled to appear in a U.S. court on Thursday as it continues its struggle for survival. The Russian authorities are dismantling the firm to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax debt. In response, Yukos sought bankruptcy protection in the U.S., hoping to leverage international business law to halt the compulsory sale of its crucial oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. Despite these efforts, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to the state-run oil company Rosneft, but not before the state auction was interrupted. Yukos' legal team now argues that the auction breached U.S. bankruptcy laws. The company and its principal shareholders have pledged to pursue any entity that acquires its assets, utilizing every available legal avenue.

Voters are eagerly participating in the annual Bloggies, which honor the best blogs—online platforms where individuals share their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the official website experienced an overwhelming surge in traffic, causing a temporary shutdown. This year, blogs have been nominated across 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs have gained significant prominence, with "blog" being named the word of the year for 2004 by a leading U.S. dictionary. Technorati, a blog search engine, monitors approximately six million blogs and reports that over 12,000 new blogs are created daily. According to Pew Internet and American Life, a U.S.-based research organization, a new blog is launched every 5.8 seconds. However, less than 40% of these blogs are updated at least once every two months.

According to Chinese state media, the China Three Gorges Project Corporation is defying a government directive to halt the construction of one of its massive dams. Despite orders, the company responsible for building the Three Gorges Dam is proceeding with the construction of the Xiluodu Dam, as reported by the Beijing News. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale projects ordered to stop due to insufficient environmental assessments. Instead of complying, the company may choose to pay fines, as suggested by the Beijing News. Additionally, the firm has disregarded instructions to cease work on two other projects: the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. To date, only 22 out of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to perform mandatory environmental impact assessments have adhered to the suspension order.

Manchester United narrowed Chelsea's lead in the Premier League to nine points following a determined 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney capitalized on Gary Neville's cross to the near post by delivering a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne, giving United the lead. Shortly after, an unfortunate Dunne inadvertently volleyed the ball over goalkeeper David James and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best opportunity by missing the target from three yards out in the first half. In the initial 45 minutes, United appeared unlikely to secure the crucial win needed to keep their title hopes alive. Their play was more sluggish than strategic, resulting in only one notable chance—a header by Paul Scholes that sailed over the bar.

The newly appointed Health Minister for Wales emphasized the importance of learning from England's approach to addressing waiting lists. On his first complete day in office following Jane Hutt's dismissal, Dr. Brian Gibbons acknowledged the "significant challenges" ahead but affirmed that the "fundamentals" were already established. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats expressed the need for Dr. Gibbons to revise existing policies. In her defense, Ms. Hutt argued that waiting times and lists constituted "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, formerly a GP in Blaengwynfi in the Upper Afan Valley before becoming Assembly Member for Aberavon, indicated that NHS staff desired a phase of stability after extensive change and reform. An ongoing issue during Ms. Hutt's tenure as the Assembly's inaugural Health Minister was the prolonged waiting lists in Wales.

Sir Alex Ferguson has commended Manchester United’s tenacity following their gritty performance in the 1-0 victory over Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away match of the season, and it was a thrilling game of football—dynamic, with excellent passing," remarked the Old Trafford manager. "We displayed immense character and determination; losing was not an option for us. Looking at that match, I feel quite accomplished knowing we've won there, whereas Arsenal and Chelsea still have to visit, and Villa might have some players back by then." Ferguson also expressed admiration for veteran players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who stepped in for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy brought the calmness we required in the midfield, something that no other player can offer," he added.

A documentary offering an unfiltered glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be featured at this year's Berlin Film Festival. Titled "A Different Story," the film will be screened in the Panorama section of the festival, which takes place from February 10 to 20. The documentary includes candid discussions by Michael covering both his illustrious career and personal journey, from his early years with Wham! to more recent events. George Michael will be present at the festival to introduce the screening on February 16. Accompanying him will be the film's director, Southan Morris, and executive producer, Andy Stephens. The 93-minute film delves into Michael's beginnings with Wham!, his subsequent solo career, his legal disputes with Sony, and his outspoken views on the Iraq War and American politics.

For the first time, digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from digital music sales, which were previously tracked only on a separate download chart. Currently, Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is positioned at number two on Billboard's Pop Chart and leads the Digital Chart. The incorporation of download sales into the UK singles chart is planned for later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to the creation of Billboard's Hot Digital Sales Chart. Now, these digital sales will be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to form the updated Hot 100 chart. Another new chart, the Pop 100, also merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits its airplay data to US radio stations that feature chart music.

The so-called "spam king" of the internet, Scott Richter, is now seeking bankruptcy protection as anti-spam laws take their toll. Richter, who runs OptInRealBig.com and has sent billions of spam emails, claims that ongoing legal challenges have driven the company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. One of the primary legal battles OptInRealBig is facing is with Microsoft, which is demanding millions of dollars in damages. The company believes that filing for Chapter 11 will allow it to address its legal challenges while continuing its business operations. Ranked as the world's third-largest spammer by the junk mail monitoring group Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for distributing emails that breached anti-spam regulations. The lawsuit was initiated by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who accuse Richter and his cohorts of sending billions of spam emails through 514 compromised internet addresses across 35 countries.

Frank Arnesen, the sporting director of Tottenham, has dismissed claims of a conflict with coach Jacques Santini, asserting that Santini's resignation was not due to a personality clash at White Hart Lane. Recent media reports suggested that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's position at the club. However, Arnesen countered these assertions in an interview with BBC Radio Five Live, stating, "That is absolutely not true. The only reason for his resignation is his personal issues." Arnesen mentioned that Santini had recently communicated to him that the matter was strictly personal. Despite this, Arnesen admitted he could not provide details about the personal issues that led Santini to step down after just 13 games in charge. He remarked, "Jacques has never shared specifics, but I trust him and believe we must respect his decision.

Ireland impressed in their quest for the Six Nations Grand Slam with a decisive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. Although Hugo Southwell's early try gave the Scots an 8-0 lead, Ireland responded with powerful scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell, taking control by halftime. Wing Denis Hickie added a third try, complemented by Ronan O'Gara's precise kicking, which totaled 13 points, further widening the gap. Despite Jon Petrie's second try for Scotland, late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy confirmed Ireland's triumph. This win sets the stage for Eddie O'Sullivan’s team to host England at Lansdowne Road in two weeks. Meanwhile, Scotland, still seeking a first Six Nations victory under coach Matt Williams, will aim to convert their competitive play into points against Italy in Edinburgh.

Britain's economic future will be the central theme of Labour's election campaign, announced Chancellor Gordon Brown. His statement followed a meeting with cabinet members at Downing Street, held just before the anticipated election announcement. Brown expressed confidence that voters would acknowledge Labour's success in fostering economic stability and growth, which they pledge to maintain. Meanwhile, the Tories have shared their strategies to address "yob culture," and the Liberal Democrats have detailed their plans to reform the council tax system. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury issued a public letter to all three parties, urging them to refrain from inciting fear during the election. He appealed for a campaign focused on solutions rather than one driven by attempts to scare the public about issues like terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Paul Brizzel to Compete in AAA's Championships in Sheffield

Irish sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among the eight athletes representing Ireland in this weekend's prestigious AAA's Championships in Sheffield. Notably, Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll, who are based in the United States, are the only Irish athletes so far selected for the European Championships who will not compete in Sheffield.

Brizzel aims to defend his 200m title at the British trials. Meanwhile, James McIlroy, currently in exceptional form on the European circuit, is looking to secure his spot in the British team for the Madrid competition by winning the 800m title. With stellar performances this winter, McIlroy is one of the world's fastest 800m runners and is virtually guaranteed a place in Madrid.

Cork's Mark Carroll, ranked third globally in the 3000m, confirmed midweek that he will join Cragg at the European Championships, where Cragg holds the top spot in the 3000m rankings.

Jason Robinson, the captain of England's rugby union team, is aiming for a significant dual-code victory against Australia this Saturday. Having transitioned from rugby league to rugby union in 2000, Robinson will lead England as they face Australia at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. Later, at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will meet Australia in the Tri-Nations tournament final. Robinson stated, "Defeating the Aussies in both matches would be a tremendous accomplishment, particularly for rugby league." England is poised to secure their third autumn international win following successful matches against Canada and South Africa, and they hope to avenge their 51-15 loss to the Wallabies in June. Simultaneously, Great Britain has the opportunity to break a 34-year win drought against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

Beware of Fraudulent Tsunami Aid Website: Internet users are being cautioned to steer clear of a deceptive website falsely claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site seems convincing as it mimics an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with this fraudulent site and has alerted the authorities about the issue. This site represents another entry in the growing list of scams exploiting the goodwill inspired by the tsunami disaster. The website's link is embedded in a spam email currently in circulation. The email is titled "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" and is riddled with poor grammar and spelling errors, common indicators of phishing scams.

Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly enhance nationwide coverage in the coming decade. The invitation is open to local, Arab, and international companies, according to Iraq's Ministry of Communications. The selected company will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to establish and operate a fixed-line network that offers voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's current telephone service penetration rate dramatically, from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within 10 years. It also seeks to develop a highly dynamic and visible telecommunications sector. Details of the bidding and tender process will be available on the ministry's website on February 9. Additionally, a roadshow for investors is planned in Amman, Jordan.

According to a two-year study, more women and older individuals are taking proactive measures to secure their home computers against online threats. The number of women purchasing software to shield PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware has increased by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. Conducted for the net security firm Preventon, the study indicates that security awareness is expanding among a diverse range of internet users. Notably, 40% of those who purchase home internet security programs are retirees, with this number rising by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Interestingly, more retired women (53%) are investing in security software compared to their male counterparts. This research highlights the evolving demographics and shattered stereotypes of web users, alongside an increasing recognition of the risks associated with high-speed broadband connections.

Podcasts herald the emergence of DIY radio, with devices like the Apple iPod and other digital music players capable of storing up to 10,000 songs. Many iPod users are increasingly filling this space not just with music but with a diverse range of audio content from various creators. This phenomenon, known as "podcasting," is championed by Adam Curry, a former MTV host and VJ (video jockey). Although the term podcasting originates from the Apple iPod, owning one is not necessary to either create or enjoy a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show that podcasters typically produce from the comfort of their own homes. The necessary tools are simply a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. Once created, these shows are uploaded to the internet for others to freely download and enjoy.

Andrea Levy, a previous Orange Prize winner, has garnered the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book "Small Island." This victory positions her as the leading contender for the overall prize, having surpassed Booker Prize recipient Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." On another note, Geraldine McCaughrean has triumphed in the children's fiction category for the third time with "Not the End of the World." Each category winner progresses to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which offers a £25,000 prize. A distinguished panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and author Joanne Harris, will convene on January 25 to select the overall winner, with the announcement to follow that evening. According to bookmaker William Hill, Levy's novel, based in London, is favored to win with 6/4 odds.

Yukos is set to return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to request sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure entity that has acquired its primary asset. Yukos has announced its intention to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. Yukos' American legal team will strive to have Baikal's assets frozen, following the Russian government's disregard for a U.S. court's order last week that sought to halt the sale. The details surrounding Baikal's background and its reasons for purchasing the unit remain uncertain. Russian media have suggested that Baikal— which purchased the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) at a state-initiated auction on Sunday—has significant ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured their spot in the Scottish Cup quarter-final by overcoming Livingston with a 2-1 victory, thanks to their remarkable start in the opening 10 minutes. Lee Miller drew first blood within the first minute, expertly heading Jamie McAllister's free kick over Colin Meldrum into the net. McAllister quickly followed up, personally adding to the score by meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the far post and sealing the game early on for the hosts. Although Craig Easton netted a controversial goal for Livingston after an hour, Hearts maintained their lead until the final whistle. The first goal was set up following a mistake by Gus Bahoken, who fouled Miller 35 yards from goal. McAllister's deft free kick found its way to an unguarded Miller, who leapt above the static Livingston defense to score from 10 yards out. Just ten minutes into the match, Hearts extended their advantage as Mikoliunas dashed down the right flank and delivered a precise cross, allowing McAllister to head past Meldrum.

Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has put bigoted soccer fans on notice, emphasizing her intent to penalize them severely by banning them from attending matches. These exclusion orders are part of a broader initiative by the Scottish Executive to combat sectarianism. Jamieson commended both Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing this issue but stressed the importance of eliminating sectarian abuse linked to Old Firm matches as a top priority. Her remarks came ahead of the Scottish Cup third-round match between the Glasgow rivals at Parkhead on Sunday. The long-standing sectarian tensions among some supporters of these clubs have now become a major focus for the Executive. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell engaged in discussions with representatives from both clubs to address this pressing matter.

Kevin Spacey's new film had its UK debut with a star-studded premiere attended by Hollywood actors Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth. The event took place on Thursday at Leicester Square in London. Spacey, aged 45, not only wrote and directed "Beyond the Sea" but also played the lead role, bringing to life the story of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This film is my homage to an extraordinary talent," said Spacey, who performed all 18 songs on the movie's soundtrack. Bosworth, aged 21, portrayed Darin's wife, the real-life actress Sandra Dee. "Before working on this project, I knew nothing about Bobby Darin, but I've since become a fervent admirer," remarked Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend, Orlando Bloom.

Leeds vs. Saracens (Friday) at Headingley, Friday, 25 February, 20:00 GMT

The Tykes have reinforced their squad by bringing in Newcastle's prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Saracens' lineup sees Raphael Ibanez starting at hooker as one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected for the pack, with Kevin Sorrell stepping in at outside centre.

Friday's match at Headingley has been confirmed after an early pitch inspection deemed the field playable.

Leeds lineup: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

The traditional landline phone in your home may soon become a relic of the past. Recent research conducted by Nokia reveals that a growing number of individuals now rely solely on their mobile phones for all their call-making and receiving needs. The study indicates that over 45 million people in the United Kingdom, Germany, the United States, and South Korea exclusively use mobile phones. While many still retain their landlines due to lower call charges, the majority of participants believe that the future lies with mobile technology. The Nokia-sponsored study also highlighted that mobile and fixed-line phones serve different functions: landlines are favored for longer conversations, whereas mobile phones are preferred for shorter chats, particularly with friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents reported choosing their landline for calls as it remains more cost-effective than using a mobile phone.

In a surprising turn of events, Jurgen Melzer defeated second-seed Andre Agassi in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. The Austrian's effective use of drop shots left Agassi struggling, resulting in a 6-3, 6-1 loss for the American in San Jose. Meanwhile, defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick made a comeback to overcome Sweden's Thomas Enqvist with scores of 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Additionally, unseeded Cyril Saulnier triumphed over fourth-seed Vincent Spadea, winning 6-2, 6-4, while Tommy Haas edged out eighth-seed Max Mirnyi with scores of 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. This marks the second victory for Melzer over Agassi in their three encounters. "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly," Melzer commented. "Facing Andre is always challenging. I aimed to disrupt his style because he can make you chase the ball all over the court like a dog.

A group of MPs has launched a detailed plan to replace the House of Lords, increasing pressure on Tony Blair for reform. This cross-party initiative has introduced a draft bill that suggests creating a smaller second chamber, with 70% of its members being elected. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers were removed, MPs and peers have struggled to reach an agreement on reforms. The group claims to have the support needed to eliminate the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government had postponed their removal due to expected resistance in the Lords, stating that success seemed unlikely. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on these reforms. It has also been suggested that Labour's manifesto might include proposals to amend at least the powers of the Lords.

Allan Scott is feeling optimistic about securing a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships following a promising start on the international scene. The 22-year-old from East Kilbride finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M. Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was a valuable learning experience, and I'm definitely not ruling out the possibility of competing for a medal next week," Scott stated. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who matched the Spanish record, while Sweden's Robert Kronberg came in second, and Haiti's Dudley Dorival secured third place. Although Scott was slightly disappointed with his performance in the final, he had previously won his heat with a time of 7.64 seconds but ran 0.04 seconds slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix Circuit final.

A woman from the United States has filed a lawsuit against Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are designed to expire on a specific date. This woman, hailing from Georgia and choosing not to reveal her identity, claims that a chip inside these cartridges signals the printer to require a refill even when it's not necessary. The lawsuit aims to include all individuals in the United States who have bought an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, known as the largest printer manufacturer globally, has not provided any comments on this legal action. It is known that HP ink cartridges use chip technology to detect low ink levels and alert users to replace them. However, the lawsuit contends that these chips also deactivate the cartridges after a set period, regardless of whether or not they are actually empty.

Virgin Radio is set to make history as the first station globally to offer broadcasts via 3G mobile networks. Partnering with the technology company Sydus, Virgin Radio will transmit on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. By the end of the year, listeners will be able to download the necessary software from the Virgin Radio website, facilitating access to this service. James Cridland, the Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, remarked, "This innovation firmly places radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution." Initially, Virgin Radio will be the first station available, followed by two additional digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland emphasized, "This application will empower anyone, anywhere, to tune into Virgin Radio using just their mobile phone.

Roxy Music is set to perform at the Isle of Wight Music Festival this June, sharing the stage with Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as the headliner for the three-day event, scheduled for June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the festival's Saturday night. The band is also in the studio working on new material, their first since the release of their 1982 album, Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the group the following year. They achieved their first hit with "Virginia Plain" in 1972, followed by other well-known tracks such as "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and their 1981 cover of John Lennon's "Jealous Guy.

Four captains from the Six Nations have been selected to participate in the IRB Rugby Aid match on March 5. Among those joining the Northern Hemisphere squad is Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, alongside Fabien Pelous from France, Gordon Bulloch from Scotland, and Marco Bortolami from Italy. Sir Clive Woodward is set to coach this Northern team in a tsunami relief fundraiser match at Twickenham, where they will face Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team. "I'm looking forward to collaborating with such exceptional players," Woodward expressed. This event will serve as an opportunity for Woodward to evaluate potential selections before announcing his British and Irish Lions tour squad, which will travel to New Zealand during the summer. "The game is set to be a spectacular event," he added.

The comedy "Sideways" triumphed at this year’s Independent Spirit Awards, sweeping all six categories in which it was nominated. It earned the title of Best Film, while Alexander Payne received accolades for Best Director and Best Screenplay, sharing the writing honor with his collaborator, Jim Taylor. The film's stars, Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen, also took home acting awards. "Sideways" is expected to perform well at Sunday’s Oscars, having secured five nominations. Celebrating its 20th anniversary, the Independent Spirit Awards recognize films produced outside the conventional studio system and traditionally take place the day preceding the Oscars. Other notable winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who clinched the Best Actress award for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also an Oscar nominee for Best Actress. Additionally, the Best First Screenplay award was presented to Joshua Marston for "Maria Full of Grace.

Two major U.S. companies have initiated advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" regarding their products and corporate practices. Walmart, the world's largest retailer, has responded to critics by purchasing more than 100 full-page ads in national newspapers. This effort aims to address concerns about its pay, benefits, and promotion strategies. Similarly, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is launching a campaign to counter "false" claims about its product, Prozac. Walmart began its initiative with ads in newspapers such as The Wall Street Journal, featuring an open letter from company president Lee Scott stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth." "There are many 'urban legends' circulating these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

The UK's opposition Conservative Party has announced a proposal for mandatory health checks for immigrants if they secure victory in the upcoming general election. This initiative targets individuals looking to live and work in Britain from non-EU countries. Those intending to stay for six months or longer—and who are originating from regions with high tuberculosis rates—would be required to undergo a chest X-ray and additional tests as needed. Furthermore, all non-EU residents planning to remain for a year or more would be subject to a comprehensive medical examination for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive tuberculosis diagnosis would lead to an automatic rejection of visa applications, while other medical conditions would be evaluated on an individual basis.

Manchester's rock band, Doves, have reached a new milestone, claiming the top spot on the UK album charts with their latest release, "Some Cities." This achievement unseats the flamboyant American group, Scissor Sisters, at the summit. The album's success follows the band's single "Black and White Town," which had climbed to number six. In the singles chart, R&B sensation Nelly has captured the number one position with his hit "Over and Over," featuring a collaboration with Tim McGraw. New singles from Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs have also secured spots in the top ten, alongside tracks by Futureheads and Usher. Furthermore, the recent re-release of Elvis Presley's "(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame" has achieved the third position, just ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up." Hip-hop artist Akon's "Locked Up" holds the fifth spot, while the highly-anticipated band from Leeds, Kaiser Chiefs, have marked their second chart appearance with "Oh My God," coming in at number six.

Mefin Davies, the prospective future hooker for Wales, is probably going to continue with Gloucester, the English team, despite interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales reports that although the Ospreys are keen on the 32-year-old player, Davies would rather remain at Gloucester. Davies, who shone in Wales' RBS Six Nations victory over England on Saturday, currently has a one-year contract with Kingsholm. However, he has shown his value to the Zurich Premiership team, making it likely that he will receive a contract extension next season. Following the dissolution of the Celtic Warriors, Davies found himself without a team and had to sign a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. While he did get playing time with the Ospreys per the Wales management's request, he expressed his frustration with his treatment before joining Gloucester.

There is growing discontent within the Cabinet over plans to divert funds from Whitehall to ease the pressure on council tax bills, as acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown announced the reallocation of £512 million from central to local government budgets. Mr. Raynsford mentioned that he has engaged in "pretty frank discussions" with his fellow ministers regarding these plans. He emphasized the importance of local governments providing quality services without imposing significant increases in council tax. The reallocated funds are part of a £1 billion initiative designed to help local authorities in England maintain council tax increases below 5% in the upcoming year, coinciding with what is anticipated to be a general election year. Mr. Raynsford also noted that nearly all central government departments have a vested interest in ensuring local authorities are well managed.

The Israeli club is turning to Africa, with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, poised to join Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is making history as the first Arab team to participate in a European competition and is set to face the English Premier League team Newcastle United in the first round. Goalkeeper Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a crucial role in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel after a short period with the South African team Hellenic. The club, which won the Israeli Cup final last season, is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. Renowned for their strong ethical principles, they are prominent advocates for peace and cooperation within Israel.

Reducing the legal drink-driving limit could save more lives than previously estimated, according to a new report. Research from University College London suggests that lowering the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood could prevent 65 deaths annually. These findings are being released by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill, which addresses speeding fines but not the drink-driving limit. Conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, the research also indicates that this change could result in 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003, potentially saving the country £119 million each year. A prior estimate from a 1998 Department of Transport report projected that such a reduction might save 50 lives annually.
