This paper introduces an innovative millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 radiation detector system designed for detecting single charged particles in external beam cancer radiotherapy. The system features a 1x1 μm² diode that captures the energy deposited by a single charged particle within the depletion region. Its array layout provides an extensive detection area of 512x512 μm². Unlike traditional methods that detect voltage drops from radiation, this system measures the pulse width, which is the time required for the voltage to return to its initial state. This approach eliminates the necessity for large, energy-intensive analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC was manufactured using the TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, with an average static power consumption of just 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The entire system's functionality has been successfully validated in a clinical setting using a 67.5 MeV proton beam.

Research shows that controlling the routing of autonomous vehicles (AVs) can help lessen the adverse effects of selfish routing on overall network efficiency. Nonetheless, it is unrealistic to assume that AVs would willingly submit to external control by a central authority. In this paper, we introduce a combined routing and pricing strategy designed to motivate AVs to participate in centrally managed system-optimal routing by offering toll savings. Meanwhile, AVs that pursue user equilibrium, along with human-driven vehicles, will incur congestion charges. We approach this issue through a bi-level optimization model. The upper level focuses on optimizing dynamic tolls, while the lower level employs a mixed equilibrium simulation for dynamic traffic assignment, accommodating both AVs and human-driven vehicles.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature-squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This advancement not only brings larger, more tangible objects into the realm of quantum behavior but also inspires the use of mechanical oscillators for processing and communicating quantum information and for serving as precision force sensors that surpass the standard quantum limit. However, the primarily linear interaction between motion and light or electricity limits access to a wider range of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy-squeezed states. Early optomechanical theories suggested that this limitation could be overcome by establishing strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations involving quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, they have yet to reach nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews are crucial for customers when it comes to making informed purchase decisions. Unfortunately, these reviews can be compromised by fake reviews or "spams" inserted by professional spammers. These spammers continue to develop more sophisticated and powerful tactics to evade existing detection methods. Capturing these spamming strategies is challenging as they evolve rapidly, vary between spammers and products, and are often unknown. Moreover, most current detection techniques prioritize accuracy but do not necessarily uphold the reliability of product evaluations. To solve these issues, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and spam detectors tactically compete, focusing on pragmatic objectives beyond mere detection accuracy. The Nash equilibrium of this game yields stable detection systems that are robust against any combination of detection methods.

We have developed single-shot shaped pulses designed for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer within a three-level quantum system configured in a lambda arrangement. To achieve high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions that facilitate exact transfer, ensuring that these solutions adhere to a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. From this family, we identify a tracking solution characterized by a single parameter, which effectively controls the fidelity of the transfer, the population within the excited state, and the robustness of the system. We define the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas that results in infidelity exceeding $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses demonstrate superior robustness compared to Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses when considering moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we explore the characteristics of the population's negative log-likelihood function associated with Gaussian mixture models, regardless of the number of components involved. Due to the function's nonconvex nature, many local minima exist, which are suboptimal on a global scale, even in scenarios where the mixture components are clearly distinct. We demonstrate that all local minima possess a consistent structural form that partially identifies the true mixture's component centers. Specifically, each local minimum involves either fitting multiple Gaussian distributions to a single true component or fitting one Gaussian distribution to multiple true components without overlap. Our findings are applicable when the true mixture components meet a specific separation criterion and remain relevant whether the number of components is overestimated or underestimated. For Gaussian mixtures comprising three components, we achieve more precise outcomes regarding the separation scaling between the components.

We examine the link between two methods for constructing the mirror partner of a Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup \( g \) of the phase symmetries of a hypersurface \( x_m \) within a weighted projective space, specified by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( w_m \). The first approach, known as the Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, involves another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface \( x_{m^t} \) within it by a dual group \( g^t \). The second approach, proposed by Batyrev, constructs the mirror partner as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the one associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide straightforward evidence supporting the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this study, we expanded upon existing models of human gait, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev, to develop a comprehensive understanding. Our hybrid model integrates a strategy for minimizing metabolic energy during a race with a non-linear representation of the movement of the center of mass, aiming to replicate the transition from walking to running. Experimental data across various speeds suggest that the trajectory's perimeter of the center of mass is a significant factor in analyzing this dynamic behavior. This experimental approach was executed in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We introduce an innovative mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator specifically designed for planetary systems, effectively addressing close encounters. This approach leverages time regularization to maintain the stability characteristics of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size when two planets come close to each other. By employing a high-order MVS scheme, the integrator allows for large time steps when planets are far from such encounters. Our results indicate that this algorithm successfully manages near-exact collisions, where the separation is only a fraction of the planets' physical radii, using the same time step applicable to less perturbed situations like the solar system. We validate the long-term performance on a system of six super-Earths undergoing intense scattering over 50,000 years. Comparing our integrator with hybrid models like Mercury, we demonstrate superior energy conservation at an equivalent computational cost.

Entanglement plays a vital role in quantum information processing. A commonly used method to identify entanglement is through an entanglement witness, where measuring the witness operator is always positive for separable states but can turn negative for certain entangled states. However, as the system size increases, the dimension of the Hilbert space expands exponentially, making it particularly challenging to design an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. When dealing with $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most resilient witness approach requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can endure up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only necessitates two local measurement settings and can withstand up to $1/3$ white noise.

In the framework of general relativity, the Kerr spacetime represents the sole stationary solution for an isolated black hole, characterized by a distinct multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. We have developed a comprehensive method to extract the multipole moments of any stationary spacetime and have applied this to a broad range of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can disrupt the axial and equatorial symmetry found in the Kerr metric, resulting in a far more intricate multipolar structure. This complexity offers a means to impose phenomenological constraints on fuzzball models. Our numerical results suggest that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute terms) than those of a Kerr black hole with equivalent mass and spin. While current measurements of the quadrupole moment in black-hole candidates impose only minimal restrictions on fuzzballs, future gravitational-wave observations of extreme mass-ratio inspirals by the LISA space mission will significantly tighten these constraints.

Understanding the evolution of graphs over time is a complex task across fields like bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. In the scenario we examine, graph edges represent either short-term interactions (such as messaging) or long-term structural connections (such as friendship). Often, long-term edges are manually defined by humans, which can be costly to establish and may not always be optimal for subsequent analysis. To address these challenges, we introduce a model that combines temporal point processes with variational autoencoders to understand temporal attention between nodes based on their communication patterns. By using the dynamics of node interactions, this method enhances flexibility and resolves issues related to manually defined edges, as temporal attention influences how features are propagated between nodes.

We report on the thermally induced transverse vibrations of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW). The waveguide is composed of two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. We have developed and validated models to translate the motion of these beams into phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe traveling through a guided mode (GM) in the waveguide. This analysis is applicable for probe frequencies both far from and near the dielectric band edge. The PCW was specifically designed for near-field atom trapping, and this study lays the groundwork for assessing potential adverse effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps located close to the waveguide surfaces. Our long-term objectives include creating robust atom-mediated interactions between individual vibration phonons and single photons traveling in the PCW’s guided modes, thus paving the way for quantum-level opto-mechanical systems integrating atoms, photons, and phonons.

We introduce natural decompositions for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms linking the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups across successive dimensions are inherently split epimorphisms. This splitting is particularly relevant in the context of equivariant stable homotopy theory. In this framework, the equivariant stable homotopy groups of any global spectrum organize into a global Mackey functor, making the splittings instrumental in breaking down certain long exact homotopy group sequences into shorter exact sequences. In the case of the real and complex global Thom spectra, denoted as $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, these splittings affirm the consistency of various Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects lead to a dampening of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on smaller scales. The uncertain shape and magnitude of this damping pose significant challenges for forthcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as those conducted by Euclid or LSST. In this first installment of a two-part series, we utilize simulations to construct a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the associated covariance matrix, both of which are adjusted for baryonic influences using the baryonification method outlined by Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we have developed an emulator to provide rapid predictions of baryonic power suppression, enabling us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard ΛCDM cosmology, incorporating both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Processing spontaneous conversations in real-world environments, like those found in child-centered recordings, is recognized as one of the most complex audio challenges. Successfully developing speech processing models capable of handling such a diverse range of conditions would greatly benefit language acquisition research, which focuses on the quantity and quality of speech children are exposed to and produce. Additionally, these models would be invaluable for early diagnosis and evaluating the impact of interventions. In this paper, we introduce our methodology for creating an open-source neural network designed to categorize audio segments into vocalizations by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations from other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we compiled a diverse set of child-centered corpora, amassing a total of 260 hours of recordings spanning 10 languages.

Density-based clustering is built on the concept of connecting groups to specific characteristics of the probability distribution that underlies the data. By referring to the true, albeit unknown, population structure, the clustering problem can be cast into a standard inferential framework. Within this framework, the notion of an ideal population clustering is defined as the partition created by the true density function. The nonparametric approach to this idea, known as modal clustering, links the groups to the domains of attraction of the density modes. In practice, this requires a nonparametric density estimate, and appropriately selecting the degree of smoothing is crucial, as it determines the shape of the density—and thus the possible modal structure—to identify the final partition. This study examines the challenges of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

Diboson production at the LHC is highly sensitive to the interference between Standard Model predictions and higher-dimension operators that encapsulate the influence of potential heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes prevent the straightforward interference of dimension-six operators, leading to a cancellation of the leading order correction to the overall diboson production rate. In such cases, precise measurement of azimuthal decay angles can "restore" the efficacy of these interferences, enabling detection of the so-called "non-interfering" operators. Our detailed exploration of these phenomena shows that the uncertainties in the effective field theory (EFT), associated with higher-dimensional operators, are significantly suppressed through the formulation of an asymmetry variable. This variable is uniquely influenced only by non-interfering operators, thus diminishing the impact of interfering, higher-dimensional operators to a level comparable with statistical errors in the corresponding observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a primary goal of numerous health and social science data analyses. Traditionally, academic statisticians have often viewed analyses with causal objectives skeptically. However, the emergence of "data science" offers a pivotal chance to redefine data analysis, seamlessly integrating causal inference from observational data. As others have done, we categorize the contributions of data science into three main tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (encompassing causal inference). Clearly defining these tasks is essential for discussing the requisite data, assumptions, and analytics needed for each. We assert that inadequately highlighting the role of domain-specific expert knowledge in data analysis contributes significantly to widespread misconceptions about data science.

The Weak Gravity Conjecture (WGC) posits that in any consistent quantum theory of gravity, there must exist superextremal particles. Conventionally, these particles are thought to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or only marginally stable. However, the consequences of this not being the case are not entirely clear. This note demonstrates that in a general Einstein quantum theory of gravity within Anti-de Sitter (AdS) space, the precise stability of extremal black branes conflicts with established quantum information theorems concerning entanglement entropy. To resolve this contradiction, the note introduces a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which aligns with the traditional interpretation in the context of weak coupling. This argument is broad, requiring neither supersymmetry nor a specific ultraviolet (UV) completion. It relies solely on the principles of Einstein gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding the emergence of unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures in strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems remains a fundamental challenge in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have become exemplary model systems due to their cleanliness and controllability, offering insights into the effects of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality. However, direct confirmation of superfluidity within these systems had been elusive. In our study, we provide evidence of superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas. This is achieved by introducing a periodic potential through the system and noting an absence of dissipation below a certain critical velocity, \( v_{\rm c} \). We have quantified \( v_{\rm c} \) across varying interaction strengths and observed a peak within the transitional zone between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our findings affirm that ultracold Fermi gases serve as a potent medium for exploring how reduced dimensionality impacts strongly correlated superfluids.

We investigate the transport characteristics and the superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions composed of a Weyl semimetal with broken time-reversal symmetry, positioned near an s-wave superconductor. Our study reveals that both the differential conductance and the induced pairing amplitudes are significantly influenced by the angle between the direction of the junction in real space and the axis that separates the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We explore how a chiral chemical potential—representing the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality—affects the junction's transport properties. Notably, we discover a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated through Andreev reflection within the two Weyl semimetal regions. This spin polarization is opposite in each of the Weyl semimetal regions and is notably sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has proven to be an effective and controllable method for modifying the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic materials, finding utility in various applications. Notably, this technique provides a way to manage voltage distribution across high-voltage insulators, thereby enhancing the maximum operational voltage that can be sustained without triggering surface flashover. However, a potential concern is the long-term stability of the enhanced conductivity from the implantation, particularly if the implanted metal is prone to oxidation. In this study, we explore the long-term conductivity behavior of titanium-implanted alumina. Our findings show that although there is an initial reduction in conductivity of up to 40% within the first few weeks post-implantation, this is followed by a very gradual decline of approximately 10% over the subsequent year.

In the realm of effective field theories for pions and vector mesons, we propose a new conserved current akin to the Skyrme model, built upon the concept of hidden local symmetry. The charge associated with this current matches the Skyrmion charge in any smooth field configuration. Moreover, there are singular configurations that can be interpreted as baryons with flavor number n_f=1, exhibiting charge under this new symmetry. Within this framework, vector mesons act as Chern–Simons vector fields existing on a quantum Hall droplet, which constitutes the n_f=1 baryon. We suggest that this current accurately represents the baryon current at low energies. Our model offers a cohesive perspective that reconciles both baryon types, enabling a natural transformation between them. Additionally, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be understood through a Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents an exciting opportunity to integrate anomalous Hall and Josephson phenomena within a single device. We conduct a theoretical analysis to explore how the interplay of these effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The skew tunneling of Cooper pairs, dependent on transverse momentum, across the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface, leads to significant transverse Hall supercurrents. We refer to these as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula—originally established to measure conventional Josephson current flows via tunneling—to assess the transverse current components. Our findings reveal that the amplitudes of these currents can be significantly tuned through the strength of spin-orbit coupling or by altering the superconducting phase difference across the junction. Additionally, as a distinct spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions, well-defined subgap bound states emerge around the interface.

In line with the findings from the Monte Carlo simulations as noted in Jiménez's study (J. of Turbul., 2020), dipoles play a crucial role in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence, comparable to that of individual vortex cores. The kinetic energy in this turbulent flow primarily resides in elongated streams composed of interconnected dipoles. The vortices divide into two distinct groups: one consisting of small, fast-moving cores, and another of larger, slower ones, which appear to be 'frozen' into a gradually developing 'crystal.' The motion of these two groups is markedly different, with only the smaller, fast-moving group displaying self-similarity. The majority of the kinetic energy is attributed to the slower, larger vortices, which form the dipoles and streams. The text also explores the processes contributing to the expansion of this slow-moving component.

Continuous-time quantum walks have become an invaluable tool for developing various quantum algorithms. The efficiency of these algorithms is often measured by the quantum hitting time, which indicates how long it takes for a quantum walk to identify a specific vertex with high probability. In this article, we present enhanced upper limits for quantum hitting time applicable to numerous algorithms utilizing continuous-time quantum walks. Notably, we apply our methodology to the glued-trees problem, resulting in a substantial reduction of the hitting time upper bound from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Additionally, our approach significantly improves the precision dependence of the continuous-time quantum walk based algorithm developed by Chakraborty et al. for locating a marked node across any ergodic, reversible Markov chain.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized into dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on how they form. Dry EMRIs, or "loss-cone" EMRIs, have traditionally been seen as the primary sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna (LISA). These are predominantly generated through multi-body scattering within nuclear star clusters and gravitational capture. In this letter, we introduce an alternative EMRI formation mechanism: wet EMRI formation, facilitated by the accretion flows surrounding massive black holes (MBHs) at galactic centers. In this scenario, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that initially move on inclined orbits and drives them to migrate toward the MBH. This significantly increases the EMRI formation rate in such galaxies by several orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we often lack any prior information about them. This means they have no history of interacting with items, no established user profile, and no connections with other users on the platform. Despite this, it is essential that our recommender systems engage new users from the outset, enticing them to remain on the site and become active participants. This challenge is known as the new user cold-start problem, and it is critical to both the growth and even the viability of a company. Current solutions for addressing user cold-start scenarios typically involve asking for additional input from users, such as through an interview process, or leveraging supplementary data like user demographics, location, or social networks [10]. Nevertheless, users might be reluctant to participate in interviews, and often, this supplementary information is not readily available for new users.

Deep learning has effectively addressed numerous challenges that heuristic algorithms couldn't tackle. It has also found success in the realm of wireless communications, despite the fact that current radio systems are thoroughly understood and many tasks have existing optimal algorithms. Although learning specific components of a receiver has yielded some benefits, a more advantageous strategy is to learn the entire receiver collectively. This approach, however, often leads to a complex nonlinear problem, making the optimal solution impractical for implementation. To address this, we introduce a deep fully convolutional neural network named DeepRx, designed to handle the entire receiver process from processing the frequency domain signal stream to generating uncoded bits, all while adhering to 5G standards. We enhance precise channel estimation by meticulously crafting the input of the convolutional neural network, integrating both the data and pilot symbols in a specific manner.

Mutation-based fuzzing begins with a starting set of seed inputs that don't cause crashes, known as a corpus, and generates new inputs through mutation. Often, a corpus may include thousands of similar inputs, which can result in redundant fuzzing efforts when all seeds are mutated exhaustively. To optimize this, fuzzing tools include distillation utilities, like afl-cmin, which help select the smallest subset of seeds capable of triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the full set. It is a common belief that reducing the number and overall size of seeds enhances fuzzing efficiency, a theory which we examine systematically. We present findings from over 34 CPU-years of fuzzing across five different distillation methods to assess their effectiveness in identifying bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we explore the concept of multi-agent discrete-event systems operating under partial observation. The agents can be categorized into groups, with each group sharing similar (isomorphic) state transition structures—allowing them to be relabeled using a common template. This template is used to develop a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost remain constant, irrespective of the number of agents involved, even under partial observation. Remarkably, this scalable supervisor doesn't require reconfiguration as agents are added or removed from the system. We extend our previous findings to accommodate partial observation by presenting sufficient conditions that ensure safety and maximize the permissiveness of the scalable, least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An example is included to demonstrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric Network Frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a highly effective tool in multimedia forensics. We introduce an advanced method for ENF estimation that incorporates temporal windowing through the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. This technique leverages the Gohberg-Semencul factorization to handle the Toeplitz structure inherent in the model's covariance matrix. Notably, for the first time in ENF analysis, a non-rectangular temporal window is utilized prior to spectral estimation, enhancing the method's versatility. Additionally, Krylov matrices are utilized to expedite matrix inversions. This innovative approach surpasses state-of-the-art methods in terms of ENF estimation, particularly when implementing a brief one-second time window for power recordings. In the context of speech recordings, our method achieves remarkable accuracy while maintaining computational efficiency.

The direpack package seeks to introduce a cohesive array of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python ecosystem. This package categorizes these techniques into three primary groups: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, it offers regularized regression estimators that utilize these reduced dimension spaces, encompassing methods from classic principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also includes a suite of both classical and robust preprocessing tools, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting features and cross-validation utilities. Notably, direpack is designed to seamlessly integrate with the scikit-learn API, allowing its estimators to be effortlessly incorporated into statistical and machine learning pipelines within that framework.

Nonlinear fluorescence emission has become a valuable tool for achieving high spatial resolution in optical imaging. In this study, we explored the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect associated with nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. When exposed to high-power laser excitation, we observed a reduction in fluorescence that increased the nonlinearity of the emission. This change altered the spatial frequency distribution of the resulting fluorescence image. To capture detailed high spatial frequency information, we employed a differential excitation protocol, which involved modulating the power of the excitation laser. This approach enhanced the spatial resolution of imaging by approximately 1.6 times compared to conventional confocal microscopy. Owing to the straightforward nature of both the experimental setup and data processing, we anticipate that this technique will be highly beneficial for increasing the spatial resolution in applications such as sensing and biological labeling using defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the typical practice of using individual survey weights—designed to be inversely proportional to unit survey inclusion probabilities—to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer leads to asymptotically unbiased inference. We propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that enables unbiased inference for generating the hyperparameters of the random effects. In comparison to frequentist methods that depend on numerical integration, our Bayesian approach is unique in achieving both unbiased estimation relative to the sampling design distribution and consistency with the population-generating distribution. Through simulations and a real-world example involving a survey of business establishments, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our method across various modeling frameworks and sampling designs. This work culminates recent advancements combining traditional survey estimation techniques with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, effectively bridging these two rich yet distinct subfields.

Two-dimensional materials with low symmetry, such as ReS₂ and ReSe₂ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene, exhibit more intricate atomic structures compared to the simple honeycomb lattices found in graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries in these novel materials lead to diverse and inhomogeneous electronic, optical, valley, and spin properties, as well as entirely new phenomena including ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave activities, significant nonlinear optical characteristics, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Additionally, these low-symmetry materials can demonstrate unique electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic characteristics, and structural phase transformations. The special topic "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" has been curated to showcase pioneering experimental and theoretical research in these cutting-edge materials.

The study of orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer, featuring both mesogenic and functional side groups, utilized the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy for analysis. This investigation revealed, for the first time, a distinct behavior in mesogenic polymers compared to low-molecular-weight mesogens: the relaxation of electric birefringence in a melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by a combination of multiple exponential processes, with two processes playing a crucial role. These primary processes take turns dominating across a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also identified two types of orientational relaxation processes: one arising from the rotation of side mesogenic groups and the other from the movement of main chain segments.

Deep hashing techniques have demonstrated exceptional accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. A central challenge in these methods is optimizing discrete hash bits. Typically, this involves using an activation function, such as the sigmoid or tanh, and minimizing a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. Unfortunately, this approach can cause hash bits to become stuck in the wrong saturated zones of these activation functions, creating what we refer to as the "dead bits problem" (DBP). Furthermore, the current quantization loss exacerbates the DBP. In this paper, we introduce a straightforward yet effective gradient amplifier, applied before the activation functions, to mitigate the DBP.

We investigate the properties of an SU(2) triplet scalar with zero hypercharge, which is encouraged by the concept of a two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking process. Our study explores two scenarios: first, where these triplets are stable and contribute to dark matter, and second, where they decay through interactions with the standard model Higgs boson. The stability scenario is scrutinized by searches for disappearing charged tracks at the LHC and by direct detection dark matter experiments. In contrast, the decay scenario faces constraints from current multilepton collider searches. Our findings indicate that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is prohibited by direct detection investigations. Additionally, an unstable triplet with a mass under 230 GeV is ruled out at a 95% confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than anticipated under the traditional model of eccentric planet perturbation, commonly known as "pericenter glow." This model suggests that a belt of planetesimals, initially circular and situated at a semi-major axis $a$, has its eccentricity elevated to $e_f$ through secular perturbations from an eccentric planet once the gas disc disperses, thereby forming a belt with a width of $2ae_f$. However, a slight modification to this model allows for narrower belts if the planetesimals originally possess some eccentricity, a condition that could arise from earlier planetary disturbances during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, this initial eccentricity might be a consequence of instabilities that amplify the disc's eccentricity, independent of planetary influences.

Traditional understanding suggests that an electron primarily exhibits a single form of kinetic energy. However, could it possess additional variations related to its spin, charge, or interactions with other electrons? In one-dimensional (1D) systems, the Tomonaga-Luttinger-Liquid (TLL) model accurately describes the behavior of interacting electrons at low energies, though experimental observations beyond this linear range have been limited. In this study, we present our findings on many-body modes in 1D gated wires through tunneling spectroscopy techniques. We detected two distinct Fermi seas at elevated energies, corresponding to spin and charge excitations, along with the development of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that become more pronounced with shorter wire lengths. The effective interaction strength within the wires was modified by adjusting the degree of 1D inter-subband screening, exceeding a 45% change.

The history of the Milky Way's assembly is gradually being uncovered, thanks to data from the Gaia mission. It appears that the globular cluster system within our galaxy has followed an equally complex formation path. To better understand this formation, we investigate the connection between these globular clusters and the known merger events that the Milky Way has undergone. By integrating Gaia's kinematic data for nearly all galactic clusters with the most comprehensive and systematically corrected sample of cluster ages, we identify clusters that likely share a common origin through an analysis of their dynamical properties, specifically within the context of integrals of motion. Our findings suggest that approximately 40% of these clusters likely originated within the galaxy itself.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a crucial step in many dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces "intrinsic," an R package featuring advanced, state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for determining a dataset's intrinsic dimension. The package includes methods such as the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To enhance accessibility, it provides user-friendly, high-level functions built on a robust set of efficient, low-level routines. The intrinsic package offers models in two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category includes the two-nn and gride models, with functions that support inference in both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. In the second category is the hidalgo model, a Bayesian mixture model, which incorporates an efficient Gibbs sampler for implementation.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, paving the way for advancements in spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. This study introduces and models two physical RC systems: one utilizing a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and the other comprising 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs). These systems were designed to tackle image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system predictions, respectively. Our micromagnetic simulations highlight the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNOs when stimulated by current pulses, demonstrating that an RC system based on a single MSM excels in image classification tasks, such as recognizing handwritten digits. Furthermore, a physical RC system composed of 24 STNOs effectively addresses complex and previously unknown nonlinear dynamic problems, as evidenced in tasks involving a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10.

Ranking algorithms are integral to the functioning of online platforms, including search engines and recommendation systems. In this study, we explore an unexpected outcome of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the number of items that signify a particular indicator, the greater the proportion of total traffic they tend to garner. This phenomenon, known as the few-get-richer effect, becomes evident in scenarios where there are limited distinct categories of items (for instance, news outlets with left-leaning and right-leaning biases) and items are ranked by their popularity. Through analytical methods, we demonstrate that this effect is pronounced when users predominantly click on items that top the rankings and exhibit diverse preferences for the categories. We further examine the effect's intensity under varying assumptions about the environment and human behavior through simulations. Additionally, we validate our hypotheses via an online experiment involving human participants. Our results offer significant insights into the dissemination of misinformation.

Weight pruning is recognized as a simple yet effective technique for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), offering the potential for acceleration across multiple platforms. However, many pruning methods compromise between model accuracy and regularity, often hindering inference accuracy and limiting acceleration performance on devices. To address this issue, we introduce a novel sparsity dimension: pattern-based sparsity, which includes both pattern and connectivity sparsity, ensuring high accuracy and hardware compatibility. By using meticulously crafted patterns, our pruning method consistently enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction across various DNN architectures and datasets. Additionally, our pattern-aware pruning framework enables simultaneous library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. This pattern-based sparsity approach is seamlessly integrated into compiler optimization, enabling highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis can be compromised by bias when the control group is significantly different from the treated group, as historical events may impact each group differently. To mitigate this bias, it is beneficial to create a more closely matched control group by aligning a subset from the overall control group with the treated group. We explore this issue through simulation studies. Specifically, we investigate the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality rates using a difference-in-differences approach, capitalizing on the surge in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. By constructing a more precisely matched control group for our analysis of MRM's effect on mortality, we established a 95% confidence interval that encompasses a range of outcomes, including significant adverse effects, no effect, and minor beneficial effects.

When developing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it's essential to assess the models' ability to accurately replicate the original data. This can be effectively achieved through visual predictive checks (VPC). VPC involves three main steps: (1) simulating multiple reproductions of the original study using the model under evaluation, (2) calculating the estimates of interest for each of these simulated studies, and (3) comparing the distribution of these simulated estimates to the actual estimate from the original study. This approach is generally straightforward and widely applicable. Our focus here is on applying this method to time-to-event data, particularly addressing the challenge posed when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be reasonably approximated after the event time.

This text introduces novel concepts and perspectives, as well as challenges, in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential methods. It explores how protocols that utilize both repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses can: (i) safeguard and confine quantum dynamics against decoherence in alignment with Zeno physics; (ii) provide an analytical prediction for the likelihood of transferring a quantum system into a targeted quantum state via stochastic sequential measurements; and (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain for a designed quantum sensor. Accomplishing these objectives will significantly enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, leading to progress in quantum science and technology.

I believe it's rare to find someone who only has a single passion they want to pursue for their entire life. In the current workforce, about 15% of American workers are not in traditional full-time employment. Instead, they are working as part-time employees, contractors, or temporary staff. The concept of a "side hustle" aligns well with this trend, where individuals combine various roles to earn a living. The term "side hustle" originally appeared in popular African American newspapers; during the 1920s, "hustle" was used to describe a scam. However, by the 1950s, "side hustle" was commonly used to describe legitimate work. Unlike a second job, which often arises out of necessity, a side hustle is more about exploring diverse interests and opportunities.

Two domes, each embodying contrasting design philosophies. One consists of thousands of steel components, while the other is crafted from a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed upon the environment, the other shapes it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by nature. Michelangelo famously said that when he gazed upon raw marble, he perceived a figure yearning to be liberated, with the chisel as his sole instrument. However, living beings are not sculpted; they grow naturally. Within our smallest units of life—our cells—resides all the information needed for each cell to function and replicate. Tools come with consequences. Since the Industrial Revolution, the design world has been largely influenced by the demands of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello, my name is Simone. You've probably heard the advice that if you feel nervous while on stage, you should imagine the audience in their underwear. This is supposed to help ease your nerves. However, I find that in today's world, doing so can feel inappropriate and awkward. Considering our efforts to move beyond such outdated notions, we could benefit from a fresh approach to combat stage fright. Personally, I think it would be reassuring to have the ability to look at the audience just as much as they are looking at me—creating a balance. If I had more eyes to match all of yours, we would all feel more at ease, don't you think?

The phrase, 'to do two things at once is to do neither,' serves as a compelling critique of multitasking. It's often linked to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, though, as is common with such quotes, the attribution is uncertain. My curiosity, however, lies in the truth of this adage. While it clearly applies to scenarios like emailing during dinner, texting while driving, or perhaps live tweeting during a TED Talk, I believe there are certain activities where multitasking—or even aiming to accomplish three or four tasks simultaneously—is beneficial. Consider Albert Einstein in 1905, when he published four groundbreaking scientific papers.

Sustainability concerns itself with the specifics of what is caught, where it is caught, and how it is caught. However, I am more interested in understanding the people involved—their motivations and their stories. I care about the individuals who contribute to my dining experience and how my choices affect their lives and vice versa. I want to learn why they fish and how they depend on the ocean's resources for their livelihoods. By gaining this understanding, we can transform our view of seafood from just a consumable product to an opportunity to rejuvenate our ecosystems. It allows us to appreciate the seafood we are lucky enough to consume. So, what do we call this approach? I believe it is best described as "restorative seafood." While sustainability focuses on enduring and maintaining, restoration emphasizes replenishing and advancing.

A starving orphan begs for a second serving of gruel. A spinster withers away in her worn wedding dress. A stone-hearted miser is tormented by the Ghost of Christmas Past. Even more than a century after his passing, these memorable characters from the works of Charles Dickens remain instantly recognizable. His body of work is so distinctive that it inspired its own adjective. But what elements of Dickens's writing make it so extraordinary? His fiction is rich with suspense, featuring brooding settings, unexpected plot twists, and compelling mysteries. These characteristics kept his readers always yearning for more. Originally, his stories were published in serial form, with a few chapters released at a time in inexpensive literary journals, before later being compiled into books.

Shah Rukh Khan exemplifies courage, determination, and a focused vision—attributes shared by the world's most successful individuals. These daring souls do not entertain the thought of failure. What might seem like an insurmountable challenge to us appears as an enticing opportunity to our next guest. She was destined to shine on the world stage. Join us as we explore the journey of our daring speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who is making a remarkable impact in the realm of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (applause)

Bhakti Sharma: Picture this: in the blistering heat of Rajasthan, on a sweltering summer's day, a young girl barely two-and-a-half years old is riding on a moped with her mother, unaware of their destination. A mere 20 minutes later, this little girl would find herself completely enveloped by water.

I'm excited to introduce a groundbreaking technology currently being developed at Oxford, which we believe will revolutionize the creation of computer games and Hollywood movies. This innovation involves the simulation of humans, complete with both a virtual body and a simulated nervous system to manage that body. Before delving deeper into this technology, let's take a moment to examine how human characters are currently depicted in computer games. Here is a clip from "Grand Theft Auto 3," a game we briefly reviewed yesterday. This game is not only highly acclaimed but also ranks among the most successful in gaming history.

This summer, much like countless others worldwide, my friends and I became captivated by the Women's World Cup hosted in France. We found ourselves enthralled by the phenomenal athletes, the breathtaking goals, and the engaging sportsmanship on display. Yet, off the field, we were equally moved by the athletes' advocacy for equal pay, with some even fighting for compensation in their respective countries. Our fascination led us to watch the matches live, so we opted to follow along on one of the Spanish-speaking networks available in the US. However, a few games into the tournament, a friend remarked, "Why does it seem like all the commercials are for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

I'd like to share with you an intriguing glimpse into the future of money, beginning with a fascinating story from a culture in Micronesia known as the Yap, dating back to the early 1900s. The Yap people had a unique form of currency: enormous limestone discs called rai stones. These discs weren't exchanged or physically moved like our coins because they could be incredibly large, with the biggest weighing around four tons and measuring up to 12 feet in diameter. Instead, the Yap maintained a collective memory of who owned shares in each stone. There's a tale of sailors transporting a rai stone across the sea when it unfortunately sank to the ocean floor. Despite the stone's loss, its ownership continued to be acknowledged by the community.

Imagine being accused of a crime you didn't commit, with no way to prove your innocence. If you protest your innocence, you're likely to be found guilty and face execution. However, if you falsely confess, apologize, and implicate others, you'll be set free. This harrowing choice plagued those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. These individuals suffered due to a paranoia about the supernatural, fervent but misguided religious zeal, and a legal system that prioritized repentance over the truth. Salem, established in 1626 by Puritans—an English Protestant group—was a community where life was strict and isolated. Conflicts with Native American neighbors and French settlers were common.

Currently, hundreds of thousands of individuals are on transplant lists, awaiting life-saving organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers. Unfortunately, the supply of donor organs is far from meeting this growing demand. Imagine if, instead of waiting, we could engineer entirely new, customized organs from scratch. This is the principle behind bioprinting, an emerging field of regenerative medicine. While we're not yet able to create complex organs, we have made strides with simpler tissues, such as blood vessels and tubes essential for nutrient and waste exchange. Bioprinting resembles 3D printing in that it uses a technique of layering materials to construct a three-dimensional object, one slice at a time.

Good afternoon. I'm delighted to be here at TEDxKrakow. Today, I aim to discuss a phenomenon that is reshaping our world, one we know as "people power." I'll begin with an anecdote, or, for those who appreciate Monty Python, a sketch reminiscent of their humor. Imagine this: it’s December 15, 2010. Someone proposes a wager—you'll gaze into a crystal ball and glimpse the future, knowing it will be accurate. Your challenge is to share this vision with the world. Intrigued, despite the risks, you accept. After an hour, you find yourself in the studios of a national TV network, appearing on a prominent talk show, recounting your extraordinary story.

Let's start in 1964. Bob Dylan, at just 23 years old, is reaching the peak of his career. Dubbed the voice of a generation, Dylan is producing iconic songs at an astounding rate. However, a small group of critics accuses him of plagiarizing the work of others. Fast forward to 2004, when Brian Burton, known as Danger Mouse, merges The Beatles' "White Album" with Jay-Z's "The Black Album" to create "The Grey Album." This remix quickly becomes an online sensation, prompting The Beatles' record company to issue numerous cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property." "The Grey Album" stands as a notable example of remix culture.

That's quite an evident statement to begin with. I first made that observation about 12 years ago, focusing initially on developing nations. However, this insight applies universally, as we all hail from various parts of the globe. Consider a map of your own country. You'll likely notice that, in every nation, there are specific areas where qualified teachers are reluctant to work. Ironically, these are often the regions that need quality educators the most and where societal issues tend to arise. In 1999, I embarked on an initiative to tackle this challenge through a straightforward experiment conducted in New Delhi.

Currently, the majority of refugees reside in cities rather than in refugee camps, accounting for over 60 percent of the global refugee population. With this urban shift, there is an urgent need for a change in approach and new strategies. Instead of spending resources on building barriers, it would be more beneficial to invest in programs that enable refugees to support themselves. When fleeing, refugees often have to leave their possessions behind, but they retain their skills and knowledge. If given the opportunity to lead productive lives, refugees can not only support themselves but also contribute significantly to their host countries. I hail from the city of Bukavu in South Kivu, located in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and I am the fifth child in a family of 12.

I have two questions for you. First: on whose shoulders do you stand? Second: what principles do you uphold? These are questions I always pose to students at the start of my poetry workshops because, often, poetry is viewed as an outdated art form dominated by old white men who seem to have been born old, much like the character Benjamin Button. I present these questions to my students and then share my own responses, summarized in three sentences: I am the daughter of Black writers, descended from freedom fighters who shattered their chains and transformed the world. They inspire me. These words form a mantra that I repeat before every poetry performance. In fact, I was reciting it in the corner over there, making facial expressions as I did so.

After graduating from a reputable liberal arts university, I didn't initially make a living from music. For about five years, my day job was quite unconventional. I was a self-employed living statue known as the Eight-Foot Bride. I love sharing this part of my life because it always piques curiosity about the real lives of street performers. On a whim, I decided to paint myself white, stood poised on a box, and placed a hat or can at my feet. When someone dropped money, I responded by offering them a flower along with intense eye contact. If they declined the flower, I would give a wistful, longing gesture as they moved on.

On October 4, 1957, the world held its breath as the Soviet Union successfully launched Sputnik, the first-ever artificial satellite. This small metal sphere, under two feet in diameter, sparked a space race between the United States and the USSR that spanned eighteen years and profoundly altered the course of history. It's worth noting, however, that Sputnik was not the first human-made object in space. That distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, which was used by Germany to target Allied cities in the waning days of World War II—a tactic that, while not particularly effective, laid the groundwork for future space endeavors. At the war's end, both the United States and the Soviet Union seized this technology and the brilliant minds behind it, utilizing them to advance their own aerospace ambitions.

I am a cultural enthusiast, one whose daily commute is sustained by my beloved iPod—a device filled with the works of Wagner and Mozart, hits from pop icon Christina Aguilera, soulful tunes by country artist Josh Turner, beats from gangsta rap legend Kirk Franklin, and an abundance of concertos and symphonies. I'm an avid reader, delving into the narratives from Ian McEwan to Stephanie Meyer, including having completed the entire Twilight series. My passion extends to my home theater, where I eagerly consume DVDs, video on demand, and an assortment of television shows. For me, series like “Law & Order: SVU,” the comedic genius of Tina Fey in “30 Rock,” and the compelling cases on “Judge Judy” are paramount—enthralling me with their authenticity and definitive judgments.

Dear Global Citizens,

We are confronted with a crisis of unparalleled magnitude. Please prepare to receive a statement from António Guterres, the Secretary-General of the United Nations. 

The climate emergency is the defining challenge of our era. We find ourselves in a race against time, and unfortunately, we are falling behind. There is an increasing sense of urgency and impatience, particularly among the youth, due to the lack of decisive global action. It is crucial that we see greater ambition from all sectors: governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals alike. 

I am encouraged by the launch of TED Countdown. Your influence and innovative ideas can play a pivotal role in accelerating progress towards achieving a carbon-neutral world by 2050. This is our only viable path to mitigating the worst impacts of global warming. We possess the tools, scientific knowledge, and resources necessary to succeed. Now, let us engage in this race with renewed political resolve and vigor.

Menstruation, a straightforward term for a natural biological process, has been burdened by centuries of stigma, forcing many of us to discuss it in hushed tones. But why is that the case? As I speak to you now, over 800 million women worldwide are experiencing their periods. This process is essential to human existence, yet it continues to be an "embarrassing" topic. From my experiences and those of the women around me, I can tell you it's draining. It's exhausting to discreetly pull a pad in a brown paper bag from your bag, tuck it into your pocket during class, and hurry to the restroom hoping not to draw attention. It's tiring to endure lessons and meetings, feigning normalcy while inwardly battling intense period cramps.

The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is located in the heart of Canada's boreal forest, the largest and most pristine forest on Earth. This vast, untouched wilderness stretches across northern Canada and is home to the George River caribou herd in Labrador, which is the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world with approximately 400,000 animals. Sadly, during my visit, I was unable to spot any caribou, though the antlers serve as evidence of their presence. Throughout the boreal forest, we are blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands. Globally, wetlands are among the most endangered ecosystems. These vital ecosystems play a crucial role in purifying air and water, sequestering significant amounts of greenhouse gases, and providing habitat to a vast diversity of species.

Before the era of humans, there existed a realm belonging to the gods, characterized by vast fields, plains, and gardens. In this divine landscape roamed four brothers. They were each other’s sole kin, their parentage a mystery. Among them was Deminan, distinguished by skin marred with painful scabs, a burden he bore alone that left him pondering its origin. One day, while the supreme spirit Yaya tended to his gardens, Deminan and his brothers stealthily entered Yaya's home. There, after satisfying their curiosity with exploration and indulgence, they noticed a colossal gourd suspended in a corner. In their attempt to examine it, the gourd slipped from their grasp and fell.

Seven years ago, I graduated from Berkeley with dual degrees in Molecular and Cell Biology and Linguistics. During a career fair on campus, I secured an interview with a start-up called Theranos. At the time, there wasn't much information available about the company, but the little that was known was quite impressive. Theranos was developing a medical device that allowed for a full blood panel using just a finger-stick of blood. This innovation was intriguing not only because it eliminated the need for large needles, making the process less painful, but also because it had the potential to revolutionize predictive diagnostics.

My journey to becoming a polar specialist and photographer began at the age of four when my family relocated from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, near Greenland. We settled in a small Inuit community of about 200 people, and we were one of only three non-Inuit families there. In this remote area, we had no television, computers, or even a radio. We didn't have a telephone either. I spent all my time outdoors with the Inuit, playing and learning from them. The snow and ice became my playground, and the Inuit were my mentors. This experience kindled my deep fascination with the polar regions.

We are often viewed as the last resort for addressing failed social policies. We cannot choose who comes to us or dictate how long they remain. We are left to manage individuals for whom all other social safety nets have failed—those who have slipped through the cracks. Other systems can't handle them, so we must. Our task is to contain and control them. Over the years, as part of the prison system, our nation, and society, we have become adept at this. However, this is not an achievement to take pride in. Currently, we incarcerate more people per capita than any other nation in the world. Moreover, there are more Black men in prison today than there were enslaved in 1850.

Let me take you on the remarkable journey of the Rosetta spacecraft, a mission that has fueled my passion for the past two years. Its purpose was to accompany and land a probe on a comet. To truly appreciate this mission, it's essential to explore the origins of our solar system. Imagine a time four and a half billion years ago, when a vast cloud of gas and dust existed. At the heart of this cloud, our sun was born and began to shine. From this same cloud emerged what we now recognize as planets, comets, and asteroids. The prevailing theory suggests that once Earth had cooled after its formation, it was struck by numerous comets. These cosmic encounters brought vast amounts of water to our planet, and perhaps even complex organic molecules that may have initiated the genesis of life itself.

Chris Anderson: Hello, TED community, and welcome back to another live conversation. Today’s discussion is as significant as they come. When we launched the "Build Back Better" series, our aim was to tackle issues stemming from the pandemic and explore how we could rebuild in its aftermath. However, the tragic death of George Floyd this past week and the subsequent daily protests have brought a new urgency to our dialogue that we cannot ignore. Can we emerge stronger and better from this? Before we attempt to answer that question, we must first strive to comprehend the vast significance of this moment.

Whitney Pennington Rodgers: Absolutely, Chris.

In 1903, the President of the United States embarked on a three-day camping expedition in California's Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt spent his nights amidst the towering sequoia trees, braved a snowstorm, and engaged in extended discussions around the campfire with his host and guide, the conservationist John Muir. While Roosevelt was an avid lover of the outdoors, Muir had a purpose beyond recreation for inviting him: Yosemite was under threat. Although it had been designated protected land since 1864, by 1903, the valley faced significant risks of overdevelopment. This was central to a longstanding struggle to reserve land for preservation while making it accessible for public use—objectives that were easier to articulate than achieve. The conflict over Yosemite's future began during the 1849 Gold Rush when miners flocked westward, searching for gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

Hello. This is my first journey outside the confines of Gaza—I have never ventured beyond its walls until now. I am thrilled to be here. (applause) My lifelong dream has been to become a pilot, to fly an airplane, and to experience the freedom of soaring through the sky. Unfortunately, that dream hasn't come true. Living in Gaza means there is no airport, and all borders are sealed off in every direction. We exist in what is one of the largest open-air prisons worldwide. My only option is to gaze up at the sky. There are days when we are fortunate if we have electricity for only four or five hours. When the weather turns chilly, we gather to build a fire either in front of or atop our homes.

I apologize, but I cannot reveal my face, as doing so would put me at risk from those who seek to harm me. My journey began 14 years ago when I was a newly graduated young reporter. One day, I stumbled upon what seemed like a straightforward story: police officers accepting bribes from street vendors. Although this issue was widely known, no efforts had effectively addressed it. As an ambitious young journalist, I aimed to present the story in a unique and impactful manner. To achieve this, I decided to go undercover as a vendor, allowing me to gather irrefutable evidence of the wrongdoing. The resulting impact was remarkable and powerful. This approach is often referred to as immersion journalism or undercover journalism.

Every day, health headlines capture our attention with claims like, "A single vitamin can lower your risk of heart disease," or "Eating chocolate reduces stress among students." We also hear about breakthroughs like, "New drug extends lives of patients with rare diseases." However, these headlines often contradict each other or oversimplify the complex findings of the underlying research. This discrepancy arises because catchy headlines tend to overlook the nuanced and incremental nature of scientific studies. How can you ensure that you’re not misled by sensationalistic headlines? The key is to examine the original research that the headline is based on. We've crafted hypothetical research scenarios to illustrate this point for each of these headlines. Stay tuned for an explanation of the first example, and take a moment to reflect when you see the headline. These scenarios are simplified for clarity.

When I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my younger brothers from Ethiopia. One day, my mom posed an unexpected question: "What date should we choose for their birthdays?" I replied in disbelief, "The day they were born, of course!" To which my mom responded, "Kristen, neither of your little brothers has a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out their actual birthdays?" This revelation was eye-opening for me. Fast forward 20 years, and I am still deeply engaged with this issue. However, instead of solely focusing on my brothers' lack of birth certificates, I am now working on finding solutions to this problem on a global scale. But you might wonder, what is the connection between birth certificates and international development?

Imagine being able to connect your mind to a device that promises endless pleasure for the rest of your life. If presented with this opportunity, would you take it? This is the intriguing question posed by philosopher Robert Nozick in his thought experiment known as the Experience Machine. This scenario invites us to envision a world where scientists have created a machine that replicates real life while ensuring perpetual pleasure without any suffering. The trade-off? You must abandon reality permanently, although you would scarcely notice the difference. Your experiences would feel indistinguishable from real life. The natural highs and lows of life would be replaced with a never-ending series of highs. Tempting, isn't it?

Let me recount the most embarrassing incident in my career as a palliative care physician. This took place a few years ago. I was called in as a consultant to assess a woman in her 70s, a retired English professor suffering from pancreatic cancer. My role was to address her issues with pain, nausea, and vomiting. During our consultation, she inquired whether I believed medical marijuana could alleviate her symptoms. Reflecting on my medical school education regarding medical marijuana, I realized, to my chagrin, that I had learned absolutely nothing about it.

For the last 24 years, I have served as a firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. My team and I are dedicated to saving lives and protecting property from various emergencies, including car accidents, house fires, and critical medical situations. As a woman leading a department in a predominantly male field, I decided to enhance my medical expertise by earning a nursing degree ten years ago. This decision was motivated by the realization that the emerging threat to my city, and others across the nation, was no longer a single, manageable disaster. Unlike before, when a firefighter could respond, extinguish the blaze, and leave with a sense of accomplishment, the challenges we face now require a more comprehensive approach to truly make a difference.

Where does all the carbon we emit go? Carbon participates in a natural cycle that permeates all living entities: it resides in the soil, the oceans, the atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When plants and other living organisms die, a significant portion of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plant life emerges to reabsorb it. Over millions of years, some of the carbon from ancient trees and marine life transforms into rock or fossil fuels like coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural occurrences, such as volcanic eruptions, release some of the carbon contained in these rocks. Human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, also release this ancient carbon. Currently, human activities release approximately 60 times more carbon annually than all the planet's volcanoes combined.

Even the most unappealing creatures in nature hold valuable secrets. Take cockroaches, for instance—despite their off-putting reputation, they possess fascinating capabilities that highlight a profound contrast between natural and human-made technologies: robustness. Robust systems excel in maintaining stability across complex and unfamiliar environments. Astonishingly, cockroaches demonstrate the ability to self-stabilize while traversing uneven terrain. When we equipped them with a jet pack or introduced a disturbance akin to an earthquake, we found that their exquisitely designed legs enable them to maintain balance without engaging any cognitive processes. They effortlessly navigate challenging landscapes, such as grass, without becoming destabilized. Additionally, we observed a novel behavior facilitated by their unique shape, which allows them to naturally roll to one side to maneuver through artificial grass obstacles. Robust systems are capable of performing a variety of tasks using the same structural framework, and this new behavior exemplifies that principle.

In these challenging economic times, fellow TEDsters, I want to lift your spirits by sharing a remarkable, though largely overlooked, commercial success story from the past two decades. This story is comparable, in its unique way, to the achievements of tech giants like Microsoft or Google. The industry in question has managed to thrive even amid the current recession. I am referring to organized crime. While organized crime has been part of society for a long time, recent decades have seen an unprecedented surge, now representing roughly 15 percent of the global GDP. I like to call this the global shadow economy, or "McMafia" for short. But what has fueled this extraordinary growth in cross-border crime?

When asked about which aspect of psychology is challenging, and prompted with "What about thinking and emotions?" most people typically respond that emotions are incredibly difficult to comprehend—complex beyond their understanding. In contrast, they tend to view thinking as more straightforward, equating it to some form of logical reasoning. However, this perception overlooks the true complexity of the situation. For example, consider this scenario: How do we address health issues? Recently, I read an intriguing claim stating that handshaking is possibly the greatest single contributor to disease spread in Western countries.

What does it mean to be a parent? This is not an easy question, especially in today's diverse family structures involving adoption, stepfamilies, and surrogate motherhood. Many parents encounter challenging questions and face difficult decisions, such as whether to inform their child about a sperm donation and, if so, when is the right time and which words to choose. While sperm donors are often labeled as "biological fathers," should we really use the term "father" in this context? As a philosopher and social scientist, I have explored these questions concerning the essence of parenthood. However, today I want to share insights gained from conversations with parents and children. I'll demonstrate that, despite the unique appearances of their families, they understand what truly matters in family life.

When I look in the mirror today, I see a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State senator. I see all of that and a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison—six years, to be precise—beginning as a teenager on Rikers Island for an act that nearly cost someone their life. However, what brought me from that past to my present wasn't the punishment I faced as a teenager in an adult prison or the severity of our legal system. Rather, it was the educational environment of a classroom that opened my eyes to possibilities I never imagined for myself or the justice system at large. Just a few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered within the prison.

When you see me, what comes to mind? Perhaps you see a woman of faith, an expert, or maybe even someone akin to a sister. On the other hand, you might perceive me as oppressed, brainwashed, or even mistakenly view me as a threat or a mere delay in an airport security line—which, humorously enough, can be quite accurate at times. (laughter) If some of your perceptions tend toward the negative, I can hardly blame you. These misconceptions largely stem from the media's portrayal of individuals who look like me. In fact, a study revealed that 80 percent of the news coverage related to Islam and Muslims is negative. Additionally, research indicates that most Americans claim not to personally know a Muslim. Perhaps this means they don’t engage much with their Uber drivers. (laughter) For those who have yet to meet a Muslim, I’m delighted to make your acquaintance.

We need to create a comprehensive water monitoring service, similar to a weather service. However, without a collective demand for accountability, there won't be sufficient motivation to finance such an initiative. The first time I spoke at a conference was here at TED, eight years ago. As a recent graduate, I wasn't aware that those few moments on stage would shape the questions I would face over the next decade. Like many people in their twenties, I was eager to tackle global issues, particularly those related to water, with my technological solutions. I had much to learn. It was tempting to believe that our major water quality challenges persisted mainly because they were difficult to detect. I assumed all we needed were simpler, quicker, and more affordable sensors. I was mistaken.

For two decades, I dedicated my career to the finance industry, fully immersing myself in the intricacies of the global economy. I was confident in my understanding of every financial nuance. Discussions on topics like ecology or apocalyptic scenarios were familiar to me, yet I regarded them with skepticism. However, in 2007, the unexpected occurred—the subprime crisis hit, leading to the downfall of major American banks. This event was a wake-up call. It prompted intense discussions with my wife about my career and the limitations of the financial model I had been a part of. The crisis led me to a profound realization: I had been fundamentally mistaken, and we were on a path towards disaster.

Are you baking an apple pie? Discount Orange Warehouse has everything you need! After all, fruit is just fruit, isn't it? In 1988, scientist James Hansen testified before the United States Congress, revealing that global warming trends are driven by human activities and will increasingly threaten humanity in the future. Remarkably insightful for the time, don't you think? Searching for the perfect wedding dress? Consider a new spin on a timeless classic—sleek, flattering, and modest, reminiscent of traditional designs. Commercials, could they be any more grating?
